Deep nut brown color, medium-sized off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits, vanilla, calvados and wood. Medium to full-bodied, liquerish palate. Sweetish flavor: lots of candy sugar, bourbon and loads of vanilla. Beer to age, but already good!

Bottle thanks to barzigkin.  Poured gold with a white head. Aroma was vanilla, Orange, and candy sugar. Flavor was pretty much the same as the aroma with a slight Belgian quality. Body was medium with high carbonation.

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours a deep, deep caramel hazy orange.  Frothy laced white head. Aroma of apples, honey, slight cedar, bees wax and slight oaky notes. Full to medium bodied with a velvety smooth, tangy palate. Flavors follow the nose; honey, lavender, and tart lemon zest.

2009 bottling. Beautiful rosewood color. Nose of molasses, vanilla, fallen leaves, sugared almonds, and wet stones. Sweet and slightly tangy on the palate with plenty more molasses, and very big yet gentle with a nice turpentine accent on the finish. Excellent indeed!

2007 bottle @ Hair of the Dog. Murky cooper with a small head. Aroma of light fruit, oak, bourbon, sugar and raisins. Flavor is sweet malt, boozy tanic oak and vanilla with a light hop bitterness. Medium to full body with mild carbonation and a thick, sugary mouth feel. This is a pretty great beer but I think I actually like the regular version better.

Getrunken beim RB Treffen in Düsseldorf am 6.1.07 
Leicht säuerlicher Geruch. Sehr fruchtiger Geschmack, dabei teilweise süß, ganz im Gegenteil des Erschnüffelten. Dieses Bier ist sehr voluminös und bleibt noch lange im Mund schmeckbar. 	 
Test vom 7.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 10,11,8,10,11,11 - 10,30

From notes:

Pours a light hazy amber orange color with a thin half finger off-white head that quickly fades leaving little n the way of lacing.

Slightly earthy aroma with zesty spice, light fruit, booze and barrel. Subtle smokiness with ashy oak an vanilla as well as hints of apple and pear.

Medium bodied and sweet with soft carbonation up front and a prominent barrel character. Huge blast of toasted oak up front with boozy sweetness that lingers throughout. Nicely balanced with hints of light fruit, vanilla, oak and booze. Subtle peppery spice adds complexity to an already crazy beer. Slightly creamy and fuller bodied than expected with a well masked ABV. Hints of apple, pear and apricot provide sweetness that adds to the insane drinkability of this beast.

Big thanks to Todd for this, batch 64, 2006 bottling!... the body is medium copper, almost golden, nice orange hue, good and unique coloring, a light tan head rises a finger but is gone to a light thin cap quickly, ok lace... the nose is really sweet, and simply smells outstanding, honey, caramel, vanilla, oak, dark fruits, integrated perfectly, the sweetness stops just short of being to sweet... the taste is more of the nose but just not totally as successful as it comes across a bit too sweet, lots of vanilla and honey, oak backbone, nice finish which shows lots of honey but some light bitter hops... mouth feel is a touch to light but passable... when most highly ranked beers fall short this one exceeded all expectations by far, this is high recommendation
Bottle.  Murky light brown in color.  Caramel and oak nose.  Fantastic barley wine with caramel, brown sugar, booze, oak, and raisin flavors.  SIMPLY OUTSTANDING.....

12oz bottle thanks to pineypower. Thanks Dean.  Pour is a nice two finger foam with tons of carbonation which quickly subsides. Color is almost amber with a reddish hint. Aroma is of stale white wine and tons of oak and some oranges. Taste... Wow.. im really starting to love barely wines big time.. this one hits you quick with orange, toffee, and tons of oak.. and then quickly warms to a nice alcohol burn... overall could have even aged longer.. but definitely solid.

Reviewed from notes.

Poured into a snifter. Color is a deep reddish-amber with a nice off-white head that settles down somewhat quickly. The nose is really nice and complex with oak, vanilla, dark fruits, figs, caramel, and some sweet malt.

The taste mixes the oak with the base quite well bringing out a bit of sweetness and fruit. Mouthfeel is really nice and rich, bringing out all the flavors that this has going on. Drinks quite well and is a really nice brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-13-2010

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2013 12 oz bottle. It is a gusher 2009 vintage.

It pours beautifully, a beautiful orange/red color with a foamy white ehad that recedes to some gorgeuos lacing.

It is straight up fucking infected though, maybe a stray batch of Fred Flanders form the wood got bottled. It smells like a sour Belgian pale. It has a bretty presence and some sweetness.

The flavor is sweet and sour with a definite oak flavor. Well ill be fucked, it isnt half bad infected. It has a big lemony flavor, some cloying sweetness from the base barleywine. Some solid barleywine base flavors like caramel and toffee are very pronounced. The wood is big and bold and it has a bit of spiciness. 

Ever had a sour Belgo-barleywine? This is it. I wish I could have it un-infected. And sadly because it is infected I have to dock points somewhere and I will go with the smell.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-15-2010 00:32:40

Another bottle, magnum as pictured. It was straight tannins, like sucking a piece of wood, no infection.

a little hazy orangish/straw/yellow color. not as copper or caramel colored as some of the other barleywines in the tasting, touch more hazy. a little bit of off-white head floating on top. 

smell is oak, vanilla, some banana-like fruit, dried fruits, and a bit of peppermint.

taste is a nice caramel sweetness that gets dried out just enough from the wood not to be cloying. a great mix of oak barrel and sweet maltiness/dried fruit, spicy tobacco notes, vanilla, a touch of old warn out hops that are only leaving a shell of bitterness to backup the brew.

nice moderate mouthfeel, maybe a hint of syrupiness. definately easy to drink. delicious beer. I think more breweries need to use clean oak in their barleywines and stouts as you get more spiciness from the wood and a dryness without adding the burn or external booze flavors.

very well done.

Bottle shared with LeopoldStoch. Pours dark orange with tan head. The aroma is wood, tobacco, spice, and vanilla. The taste was really surprising. The wood comes through very prominently but there is a rye flavor to this that compliments the the wood so well. The rye flavor is kept in check by subtle vanilla and tobacco notes. The 10% alcohol is very well hidden. I was pretty damn surprised how much I enjoyed this beer and even more surprised that I liked it better than Cherry Adam from the Wood.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2011 Bottle. Poured into a tasting glass a slightly murky amber orange color with a slight tan head. The aroma is fairly complex and stands out from the other BWs I had this night. The barrel is front and center and is very noticeable. After the barrel notes, other flavors make their way in the nose like some spice, dark fruit, and a slight vegetable aroma. Very sweet start in the taste of raisan and/or prune, barrel, and minimal hops. All the flavors are well integrated and work well together. The booze is eveident but not overpowering. Very tasty.

2009 bottle into snifter at cellar temp. Beautiful lacing and nice dark orange translucent pour. Aroma is raisins, other dried fruits, malty over the top and consistent with taste. Sweet and a bit tart, almost no bitterness to speak of. Cherries, oak, almost overpowering and too unbalanced. Not my favorite but glad to have tried it.

2008 vintage enjoyed on my birthday.  Pours a lovely red-brown hue with a thin layer of beige foam that soon dissipates into nothingness.  Aroma is quite interesting and complex with lightly candied dried fruit, honeysuckle, spicy wood, caramel, a bit of booze, and a very light whiff of smoke.  Flavor is lively with honey, fruit (kinda hoppy citrus), spice, sweet caramel, and some alcohol.  Finishes with some booziness.  Its a big beer, but at the same time its quite nuanced and even subtle and delicate.  Not so different from the regular Fred, but the wood adds a nice dimension.  After drinking lots of Angels Share around these parts, its nice to see a similarly complex barley wine without having all the roasty notes.  (564, 450)
Bottle 12 oz, Orange pour, oak, nutmeg, toffee, brown caramel malt, in aroma and taste. Buttery texture. Vanilla and wood after finish. Great beer this was. Really tasty.
1/15/11.  Liter bottle shared at the Sea Bass tasting.  Dark fruits and molasses with a woody aroma as well.  Sweet molasses, dark fruits, figs, and more.  Nice!

2008 Bottle.  Aroma has notes of over ripe fruits, honey, caramel, vanilla, oak and toasted malts.  I could just live in that aroma.  Murky medium brown hue with a small off-white head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter.  Palate is very full bodied and oily soft with a slight cloying on the long finish.  Overall a beautiful Barley Wine that has aged incredibly well.  Very rich and complex.  Lovely.

Thanks to fishingnet for sharing this one at the So Long to Sea Bass Tasting.  Pours yellow-orange with a white head.  Nose is caramel, malt, toffee, sugar, honey, raisin, vanilla, wood, and a ton of beautifully blended sweetness.  Flavor is a symphonic blend of malt, barrel, vanilla, a hint of booze, and toffee, a hint of fruits, and some brandy.  Medium-bodied and a new favorite beer.

Tasted on 1/16/11 from a 12oz bottle obtained in a trade, 2009 vintage.  Pours cloudy but bright orange with just a slight red tint and a thin white head that recedes to nothing but the thinnest collar of lace.  The nose is primarily dominated by oak with dill, cinnamon, and coconut with caramel malt, toffee, and just a hint of hops bitterness.  The flavor is sweeter with caramel, brown sugar, toffee, vanilla, and chocolate up front, moving to the dill, cinnamon, and coconut from the oak and featuring some nice bitterness on the back.  The body is full with average but stinging carbonation and a very long finish that runs the gamut of all of the flavors mentioned above with an added roasted note.

12 oz bottle (from a trade, iirc) from 06/06 consumed here in January 2011 to celebrate a good news.  Has a slightly unlevel cap, Ive never seen a bottle like this.  Very low carbonation, but it did hold.  Nose is huge, intense, complex, and room-filling; tobacco, plum, caramel, oak, vanilla, cherry, red berry, light chocolate, smoke, and some lighter aging-effects (sherry, Madeira).  Super rich malt, but doesnt seem to cloy.  Opaque mahogany with faint ruby hues, supports a short but lacing and clingy film of a beige head.  Taste is alcoholic, thin-bodied, not all that sweet, has woodsy and vanillin oak, tobacco and faint tar, but really comes through with a forward leather quality, I can just imagine it bending and making noise.  Faint mint and tea leaves under the tobacco, sweet grape and end-product wine, low-to-medium bitterness.  Caramel morphing into toffee, with cherry and rising citrus (and sweetness) and strengthening resin.  Just a touch of grass clippings - its surprising that this much hop presence remains, and that it only started to come to the fore after a few ounces.  Very slight hint of tart.  Aftertaste is in the gummy caramel category but has mellifluous honey around the edges.  Mouthfeel is, again, thin, but smooth without dragging, luscious without preening.  Alcohol is very well-integrated (Ive had seven-percenters that were more obvious) and Id bet that time has siphoned off some of the syrupy feel that plagues this kind of beer at a young age.  I love rating (and above all, tasting) Alans beers because of their depth - this is developing into a small encyclopedia of flavor terminology, and most impressively, the components work well together without jarring.  Stunning, a clear masterpiece.

Poured into a snifter.  2009 vintage.

3.5  A:  Murky light brown color.  About one finger of creamy beige head that falls rather quickly and leaves a small incomplete ring of lacing. 

3.5  S:  Holy shit is this woody!  This is simply dripping with the essence of oak.  Really, the oak is so strong that it covers up a lot of the other aromas, but Ill try to pick them out anyway.  Sweet caramel and toffee, boozy, apricot and pear brandy, plum and raisin, vanilla, and tobacco.  You really have to like wood to like the way this smells, I think theres just a little too much.

3.5 T:  Again, strong oak, tobacco, pear brandy, plum and raisin, and tobacco.  Vanilla from the oak, toasted malts, nuts, and bread.  This is really boozy for 10%.  If I had to guess without already knowing, I would have thought this was at least 15%.  Strangely, this has the essence of a bourbon barrel without the bourbon, but not just the oak if that makes any sense (I doubt it does).  This is absolutely packed with flavor, but it seems raw even with over a year of age on it.  

4.0 M:  Heavy body.  Good moderate carbonation.  Reasonably creamy, but a bit chewier than I prefer.

3.5  D:  This has the makings of a fantastic beer, but I think it needs a good three years to get to that level.  Even though this bottle had over a year on it, the taste was too earthy and raw.  I love oak, but I found it to be a bit too aggressive.  Also, the alcohol is way too apparent right now.  Its quite boozy for only 10%.  Great beer, just not yet.

Smell of caramel and sour orange liquor and light smoke.  Flavor is off the charts, out of left field type crazy.  Bready, funky, slightly sour,  toffee, old citrus peel and a raisin like sweetness take over and leave you mystified. Flavor profile doesnt make sense at all but it works so well.  mouthfeel is sticky and sumptuous, really satisfying in a dessert type way.  Thank you so much Hair of the Dog.  2009 12 oz.

At HOTD, day off Matt release. Typed up on my notes ad my phones batteries were on their last legs. 2008 Vintage. Deep amber clear brew, nice sized off white head with good lacing. Caramel, toffee almond raisin chocolate faint sourness. Awesome. T: caramel toffee nuts random red fruits med bitterness, lots of oak, dull dark cherry, light bitterness. Easily the best beer of the day....... or week up to this point.

08 bottle. It pours orange with a thin orangy head. The aroma is woody and tart with oranges and toffee. The flavor is sweet and fruity with oranges, grapefruit, caramel and a bitter woody finish. Low carbonation, but enough to be enjoyable. A unique wood aged barleywine.

Rating #900 - a 2008 12oz bottle from the brewery.  Burnt orange-brown pour with a finger of sturdy off-white head.  Big sweet woody malt aroma with apricot, vanilla, alcohol and honey.  Taste is smooth for what it brings - tobacco, caramel, grape, oak, wine type booze, apricot/dried fruits, tart oranges, and a bourbon sweetness.  The texture was perfect - rich and creamy.  The booziness complements things well.  Another great sipper from hair of the dog.  As big as this is, its mighty drinkable.  I imagine the couple years of aging served it well.  Amazing stuff.

A: The pour is a deep, dark red-orange featuring a thin off-white head.

S: Quite a complex nose. The oak is strong up front along with some vanilla notes. Plenty of fruits follow; oranges, cherries, red grapes, and other assorted dark fruits provide a nice sweetness.

T: The oak is not quite as intense initially. Sweet caramel and toffee along with an intense fruitiness. There is a mild bitterness, possibly imparted from the oak. The wood is not as heavy on the vanilla, but provides a bit of a spicy note. Just a touch of chocolatey oxidation to finish things off.

M: The body is medium to full with a somewhat low and smooth level of carbonation.

D: I liked this quite a bit better than regular Fred. Very, very complex and enjoyable.
Pours a murky medium brown, nose is very oaky, hint of alcohol, deep cherry tones. Taste is remarkable, complex tannic, cherries, vanilla, caramel, tobacco. Top shelf shit right hurr.

22oz 2008 ed courtesy of NYbeer. Pours a clear orange gold (later hazy brownish gold with the yeast) with a medium, thick, rocky, yellow head that has very good retention and all sorts of crazy lacing on the tulip. Aroma at first is sour/wild. Lots of white grapes, funk then moves to buttery bourbon, tamarind, mint, beautifully aged cognac, awesomely subdued spicy alcohol, sweetened grapefruit sections. Taste at first is actually very tart, spicy creating a sour, tingling on the roof of the mouth. Then moves to crackery malt, dough, dry and chalky biscuit with muted but still evident citrus hop balance. Not as complex or rich as the nose but still well integrated albeit lacking in palate. Mouthfeel is rich, chewy.

A reddish dark amber Fred with a thin off white head. An intense and just superb sweet grapes in wooden barrell aroma, wood extracts, musty. In mouth, a hyper smooth blend of sweet candy sugar, funk barley wine qualities, plum jam and maple. Wow and rewow!  On tap at Hair of the Dog, Sept. 4, 2010.

Thank you John!  09 bottle.  Warm/orange/honey glow in the glass - looks beautiful.  Oak, tart/fruit, smooth underlying malt in the initial aroma.  As the beer warms the aroma goes predominately oak, sweet malt and honey and the tart fades to the background.  Taste is not tart but very smooth, honey-like barley wine with a tinge of alcohol-tart in the finish.  Light and enjoyable feel in the mouth.  Tightly engineered caramel and sweet malt in the final 3rd with a clean oak influence.  Some light fruit notes at the end (apricot, melon?).  Great beer.

355 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu. 2008 version.
Pours a deep brown colour with a foamy white head. Very BW-like on the nose with medium sweetness, hops, caramel malts, syrup and milk chocolate. Very rich taste of sweet caramel, hops and syrup. Full/medium bodied with rich oily mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. Nice BW with a warming finish.

33 cl bottle from 2008. Pretty high carbonation level on this one. Take care when opening.
The body is dark amber with a huge tanned foamy head. The nose is really complex. Im thingin burned figs soaked in port, cloves and prunes and there is a little bit of smokes and some caramel and citric notes aswell. The wooden notes are notable along with the touch of alcohol.  A really nice and rich flavour taste along with a nice creamy mouthfeel. The finish tends to be a little anonymous compared to the main impression.  The alcohol makes you warm and are revealing it selfs in the finish with a biting attitude. The taste is packed with caramels an spices and some citric notes like in mandarines: Im not a great fan of barley wines that often tends to be too sweet. With this one it is different - its both sweet and fresh and with a very nice balance. A great beer.

Bottle, 2009. Poured medium amber with bright orange hues when held to the light. Head is white, thin, filmy, yet lasting. Fantastic aroma! Really fruity, approaching kriek levels. Kind of funky with a bit of vanilla and wood scents. Unlike the tart/sour cherry aroma the flavor is highly sweet with some honey, caramel, and some alcohol presence as it warms. Incredibly mellow palate. Soft, smooth, good carbonation, and flows with ease. Im really feeling this beer. Honestly, might be one of the best beers Ive ever had.

12oz glass on tap at the HotD Tasting Room.  Pours a transparent, ruddy amber with an active white head.  Nose was really great, woody, vanilla, fine bourbon, caramel, I got some apple brandy.  Flavor was sweet, very well balanced, caramel, oak, bourbon, toffee, apples, vanilla, a little fruit punch.  Full bodied, slight alcohol burn.  Loved it on tap, not sure how the bottle will effect it.

12oz. bottle, RateBeer Special Release 06/06, Batch 64.  Fruity, sweet aroma, intriguing, redolent of pineapple and oak with lighter notes of red grape, toasted caramel, spruce, vanilla, yeast esters and faintly peppery alcohol.  Hazy deep copper color with a lasting, fine head and a thin curtain of lace.  Flavor profile is sweet, malty, fruity, woody and vinous, these elements blending masterfully, with fading suggestions of dark honey, citric and spicy hop, mild bitterness, earth, tobacco, raisin and blood orange.  Smooth, full, expansive mouthfeel, gently warming with a rich body.  Has certainly held up very nicely.

bottle pours hazy light amber with a medium tan head.  Aroma is fruity, figs, apricots, light booze.  Flavor is sweet, lots of vanilla and earthy wood notes, an excellent sipper.  Dried fruits, lots of heavy booze and aged hops.  Excellent!

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2013 Bottle. Pours a cloudy gold with a light, filmy head. Aroma is oaky and sweet, with alcohol and caramel notes. Flavor begins sweet with more caramel, bready malts and golden raisins. Medium to full bodied with relaxed carbonation and some warmth. Finishes rather sweet with mild bitter notes, booze and lingering malts. Excellent beer all around. (4.3)Bottle at Pauls Birthday Drinks - CBC Clerkenwell, London. Bottle Vintage 2008. Great stuff. Some bread, rich gingerbread like, a bit of brown sugar. Full, rich. Yeah, still great stuff. (4.1)

The Dan Journal #391. Tasted 8/9/10. 12oz bottle. Relatively clear with a lively body. Reddish amber hue. Moldy off-white head. The initial olfactory emanation is thick with the woody, oaky vanilla note. Lotta wood with a decent alcohol burn in the mix. Mild doughy malts and sweet breads. Full bodied and very sweet. That, mixed with a rich vanilla wood aspect and a punch of alcohol burn. Dried dark berry esters. Toffee and dark toasted malts. Very sticky body with a lingering finish. Good burn that also lingers into the finish. Trace bitterness and mild hops. Total quality!
Another Honkeybra crush.  Very fruity nose and flavor with the oak adding a mellowness to it.  Very, very dry finish with the combination of hops and the oak.  Kinda earthy, pretty awesome.

Bottle. Amber beer with a cream colored head. Malt and caramel aroma with oak and some fruitiness. Malt and toffee flavor with oak and red fruit. Medium-plus bodied. Oak and vanilla lingers with toffee and red fruit. Brown sugar, oak, and sherry throughout.

(Bottled, 2008 vintage, sampled 2010-03-24) Clear copper with a small head. Very complex nose with strawberry fruitiness, bretty tart oakiness, vanilla, whisky-like warming alcohol, and grainy malt. Very grainy-malty flavor with oaky tannins, vanilla, tartness and dark fruit. Full body with low CO2 and slight alcohol burn. A delicious and quite balanced barley wine.

Bottle shared by drewbeerme. Pours a nice hazy ambear, lighter and lively with decent haze. A small whitish head dies to a film. Aromas are caramel, toffee, pale malts, a touch of cherry, decent florals, a light booziness, vanilla tannins and oak. Complex. Intitial is sweet, cherry and toffee mix with toast, sweet malts, a decenmt oak and vanilla tannins. Tasty, sweet. Nice

Bottle shared with my son, Keith at Union Jacks Inn on the Manatawny.  Translucent amber body with tons of floaters and a light tan head.  Sophisticated and complex flavors dominated by lightly toasted malts, vanilla beans, and light fruits.  This barleywine is superb.

In short: A rich¸ boozy and decadent barley wine with a very strong oaky character
How: Bottle 12oz.  A few times.  This rating for a 2008 vintage consumed when about 2 years of age.
The look: Partially cloudy dark golden body topped by a persistent small off-white head
In long: Nose has quite a bit of oak barrel, vanilla, fruits.  Taste is rich and complex.  Plenty of caramel, plenty of cedar, bread crust, booze, strange oaky sourness.  Very sweet but with such a rich decadent body Im ok with it.  The beer is a little too boozy for me, if anything I would have guessed more than the actual 10%.  I have tried fresher vintages and older vintages of Fred From The Wood but I always found the regular Fred a superior beer.  I dont understand why Fred From The Wood is rated higher than regular Fred.  Maybe because of rarity or maybe because beer geeks really have an unconditional love for booze and barrel flavors.  
Im now on a mission to make people realize that barrel aging a perfectly good beer does not improve it.  Ive tried to yell it in a megaphone nobody cares.  However I have noticed that people will believe what you quietly whisper in their ears.  Ive got a lot of work ahead of me.

Rapture.  In. A. Glass.  This beer has everything.  It crosses so many delicious borders all at once.  It has such a sweet note to it, very sugary -like a tripel or a belgian strong -but not candy sweet.  It is still backed by a little bit of bite to it, bitterness and alcohol like a barley wine.  But is so mellow -and the wood flavor comes out right at the end, just ...just fantastic.  Back to it tho-  This has a slightly smokey, ginger, raisin brown sugar and molasses scent.  Flavor is like overly ripe banana in its sweetness and softness, but cuts with some bitterness and the alcohol.  This is fantastic stuff.  Many many many thanks to Chucks in Chagrin to having one bottle of this in the back actually for sale.

Surprise bottle with many thanks to riversideAK! Pours a murky nut brown color with white head. Nose is apple tart, cinnamon, baked fruits, oak and dark fruits. Taste is very smooth caramels, cinnamon, oak, vanilla, lightly toasted almonds and nutmeg. The caramel really shines through.

2008 bottle.  Aroma is sticky sweet caramel, booze, and oak.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is rich caramel, smooth booze, subtle notes of tobacco and brown sugar, then finishes with a touch of semi sweet stickiness from the caramel.  This is a really fine brew.  Reminds of the BA Shoreline brew I had earlier tonight.  A lot.  Thanks Eric for sharing!!

Bottle. Cant remember where I opened it. Orange poyr with almost no head. Although not a still pour. Sweet malts, including sugars and some vanilla, oak and bourbon from the barreling over coming the normal fred flavors.

This poured a semi cloudy yellow to orange with a large offwhite head. Aroma was dark fruits, oak, bourbon, and caramel. Flavor was sily smooth caramel and toffee barleywine flavors, some fruitness too, blanketed by bourbon oak and vanilla. Excellent stuff.

Appearance: Pours a dark golden amber with a tight, white 1/4 cap of foam.

Aroma: Toffee, coconut and booze.

Taste: Wood, caramelized grapes, red apple, spicy hops and bourbon.

Mouthfeel: Very fizzy and full bodied. A tad creamy even.

Overall:  I like regular Fred better. This didnt go down easy for me. I know its designed to be a complex sipper, but it was a bit much for me.

12oz, 2008 bottle via trade with phaleslu, thanks Peter! Pours a hazy, darker orange-red colored body with a finger-width, creamy and frothy, khaki head that dissipates slowly and leaves a ton of soapy lacing that never goes away. Aroma is very nice and complex. Bursting with vanilla, citrus, oak, caramel, prunes, figs, maple syrup, and melons that all integrate nicely. A light tobacco, herbal spice, toast, resin, and just a hint of alcohol. Flavor is still a bit hot and seems to lose some of the complexity, but remains very nice. Lots of sweet and rich caramels, toast, and oak up front. Plenty of vanilla and maple syrup as well as raisins and citrus. The oak grows in the finish along with a touch of tobacco. Lots of fruity hops and some herbal spices as this finishes a bit tart with plenty of wood. Dry with a noticable alcohol heat. Lengthy aftertaste following a medium-full, somewhat sticky body and higher, soft carbonation. Overall, a well done, very strong barley wine. Lots of oak and vanilla, but plenty of rich caramels and fruity hops. This was aged nicely.

(12oz bottle batch 64 thanks to Walt) clear amber with off-white bubbles on top. Nose of caramel, herbs, brown sugar and barrel. Taste of brown sugar, wood, caramel, toasty crackers, chocolate, this beer is rich and decadent. Perfect carbonation with a long finish.

Appearance: Reminds me of that old Fender "Sunburst" brownish orange color found on lots of vintage guitars. Slightly cloudy body with a one finger white crown that shows some retention and lacing.

Smell: Oak and lightly roasted malt. some plum and or fig too.

Taste: A touch hot and disjointed. Age would probably serve this brew well. Lots and lots of oak throughout.

Mouthfeel: On the thin side of medium with a decent amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: boozy and disjointed fresh

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-07-2009

Bottle thanks to Suzygreenberg. Pours a hazy orange gold with no head. Aroma is hot with an alcohol burn, apple, apricot and oak on the nose. Flavor has a strong apricot note with undertones of alcohol, apples and a hint of oak.

12 oz bottle thanks to suzygreenberg
Appearance : Nice amber color with no head.

Aroma : Big fruity dry apricots. Syrupy with hints of tobacco leaves. Hints of alcohol. Feels a bit sour, probably from the oak. Very rich

Taste : Taste also rich and oaky. Very sweet and fruity and a bit sour. Warm and sweet finish. Gets more oaky at the end.

Overall :  This is very well made. Its my second HOTD brew (the first being Adam) and I think this is not really my thing. I can easily see the quality in this but it doesnt hit the sweetspot for me. Maybe its because of the oak sourness. I think its the same thing that i dont like in Rodenbach... yeah I know its kinda weird ...

12oz bottle, 2009 edition, from south bay. pours a beautiful, hazy, reddish-copper with a thin, whispy, off-white head and a light ring of lace. aroma is fantastic with elegant, pure, freshly cut oak layered over mild fruit notes of orange, apricot, and pear, with sweet notes of butterscotch, vanilla cake, and a hint of piney hops. flavor is wonderful as well with the citrus notes of grapefruit and orange taking a front seat to the sweet vanilla and oak from the barrel and backed by light caramel, fig, and a hint of smokey chardonnay. palate is on the fuller side of medium bodied with perfect carbonation a slight touch of alcohol warmth within the sweet, oakey finish. overall, a beautiful beer and a masterful example of barrel aging.

courtesy of tpd975.
09 bottle.
pours copper/orange, off white head.
Aroma of caramel, grapefruit, oak barrel goodness white grape giving a nice fresh white wine aroma.
Flavor, thick wood/barrel palate, thick malty caramel mouthfeel with some dark sugar, dark fruits, white grape/wine-like freshness of the barrel that reminded me of French oak, but apparently this is American oak.
Nicely done. As with the rest of HOTD beers, its always hard to see the last drop disappear.

A: Pours a nice shade of golden orange. Nice tight white head. It quickly dies but can be refreshed with a simple swirl. Nice thick spots of lace.

S: Wonderful sweet malt aromas. Lots of gooey caramel, brown sugar, and light citrus. Lots of barrel stands out as well. Fresh cut oak, light vanilla, and a hint of sweet apples.

T: Wow what a tasty treat. Wonderful sweetness up front. Apples, light pine, and all the candy malts. The barrel is there. Lots of fresh lightly spicey oak. Hints of caramel, and light booze.

M: Rather full in body, rich, sticky, lightly boozy, good!

D: Its a sipper, but a very well crafted beer! Glad I have another to lay down for a few years.

2008 vintage.
Poured with a thick, fluffy white head which stayed put for quite some time. Little bubbles cascade upwards through a beautiful, hazy golden brew. This one looks tremendously inviting.

Aromas of leather, tobacco, pears and dried apricots.

Huge flavors come from this one. Loads of pineapple, citrus up front lead to a huge hoppiness, especially as it warms up. More flavors develop (fruit stripe gum, canned peaches) almost masking a slight cardboard note, before finishing with a nice bitterness. Alcohol is pretty well hidden, but this one warms you up. Very nice.

Bottle. Light unclear copper/red body with a small offwhite head. Aroma is raisin, caramel, oak, fruity notes and vanilla. Flavor is caramel, hops, oak, alcohol, raisins. Long alcoholic and bitter aftertaste. Medium carbonation, nice lacings.
Pours amber with a large white head. Aroma is sweet caramel, plum, raisin, vanilla and oak. Flavour is sweet caramel, high alcohol, plum, raisin, vanilla and oak. Pure niceness.

Hazy orange pour with a loose white head.  The aroma is sweet clover honey, oak, vanilla, butterscotch and some subtle lactic tartness.  The flavor is buttery with notes of caramel, oak, toffee, some slight sourness and a piny bitter finish.  Creamy medium-full body with moderate carbonation.

2yr old bottle. Pours hazy orange with no head to it. Nose is a sweet vanilla, oaky, and dried apricots scent. Very low carbonation. Taste was sweet and sour. Some orange, vanilla, oak, sweetness, and tartness. I thought I was going to enjoy this one a lot more. Solid over all but did not blow me away.

Pours deep red with dissipating head, aroma is full of caramel and toffee with some pine notes.  Taste is huge and complex, starting with vanilla, oak, lemon, pear, apricot, and some dark fruit going into toffee, caramel, and a sweet candi sugar finish.  What an excellent brew.

Pours murky brown. Aroma- yeast, sugar, pale malt, wood. Taste-  darker and richer than Fred with a ton of woodiness. Has qualities similar to a oaky cabernet, but sweeter and much more full bodied. Great.

Pours amber orange with a thick beige head and a sour fruit and alcohol aroma. There is a delicious, complex flavor that includes caramel malt, treacle, dark fruit, oak and a hint of chocolate. There are equal portions of sweetness and bitterness, and a slight alcohol trail. Very well done.

Pours an unclear, dark amber beer with a weak head. The aroma is sweet, fruits, wood and vanilla. The flavor is sweet with wood and vanilla. The palate is likewise sweet. Overall a good balanced and complex beer.

#1000! Pours hazy orange. Nose is caramel, toffee, raisin, cherry, grapes, hints of tart, booze, oak. Flavor is huge toffe, alcohol, cherries, fig, plum, fresh wood, tongue burning booze, caramel, sweet syrup. Insanely complex.

I couldnt of asked for a better introduction to HotD. Appeared in the snifter a sunset reddish orange with a slight haze in the glass. No head to speak of. A delightful aroma of oak, vanilla, tobacco, funk and ripe fruits. Theres so much going on here...its ridiculously complex. The flavour is cherry tart, oak, vanilla, tobacco and pepper. Dry and tart finish. A sip and savour moment - amazing beer and great company to match. Huge thanks again to volcanicbeat for acting on impulse and bringing back a bottle to share. Cheers mate!

Wow. Oh my. Where to start. This is one of those beers it would be a shame to drink by yourself - its a real talker. Nose is Marmalade, bubblegum, funk, oak, cherry, maple and others. In the mouth it is smooth but full bodied, almost honeyish in texture. Changes throught the glass. Flavours of marmalade, oak characteristics, citrus and pine hops and a myriad of other flavours. A real event.Thank you Thank you Thank you to volcanicbeat for sharing this gem. From a non BW fan this is of the highest quality and transcends the tag.

pours a hazy amber color with a medium sized light tan head.  touch of sediment is visible.  aroma has caramel, vanilla, some fruity sweetness, faint orange blossom, and alcohol.  flavor is also sweet with vanilla and caramel, fruityness, a bit of wheatiness, and finally some hoppy woodiness in the end.  mouthfeel is slightly thick and lively with a ligering dry, earthy finish.  really nice barleywine!

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy deep amber color with a large fluffy off white head.  The aroma was caramel malts, fruity, citrus, oak, earthy hops and somewhat floral.  The flavor has nice caramel maltiness, ripe fruits, and oak.  An earthy bitterness adds some balance to the malts.  There is just a hint of alcohol which is good for a 10% beer.  Medium-full bodied and very smooth.  This is a sipper.  I wasnt expecting the amount of carbonation that this had and paired with a very mild tart flavors I wonder if this had some slight infection to it.  Overall, this was still good, but could it have been better?
Orange brown pour with a thin white head.  Oaky aroma with vanilla and wood.  Slight funk in the aroma.  Slightly sweet and sour malty flavor.  Lots of oak to finish.

Rating from memory.  Sampled at the brewery during the 1st Annual (2009) Zwickelmania in Portland, OR.  Very complex beer.  Both aroma and flavor have plenty of sweet malty notes and wood.  Mouthfeel is full bodied...viscous and sticky.  Will re-rate this one when I come across it again.

12oz bottle, 2009 edition. Sampled alongside Fred batch 76. Pours hazy reddish amber, topped with a modest sized tan head. Beautiful wild aroma, with lots of oak, vanilla, toffee, cherry, and tobacco. Vanilla and oak are primary flavors and are nicely complimented by caramel, dark fruit, pepper, and earthy hops. Medium bodied. Flavor is  great, but not as exciting as the aroma.

2009 Bottle from Beerlando (I think). Pours a nice gold with reddish tinges. nose is actually a bit funky, like underripe clingfruit and a kiss of vinegar. The hops press through as well, giving up pine and grapefruit. On taste, this is badass. A sweet oaky-ness comes through, followed by juicy peaches and apricots and a strong bitterness to balance. There is a bit of sourness on the finish as well as some bitter honey notes. This is one of my favorite barleywines of all time.

2009 vintage.

Its been a while since Ive had a Fred unfortunately, so I cant really compare them to each other which would be nice.

A - Deep hazy copper with a finger of tan head. Head dissipates quickly with no lacing, but leaves an oily film almost.

S - Barrel aging is apparent in the nose. Oak, malts, spice, vanilla, molasses, decent citrus hops, and a tinge of alcohol.

T - Im really enjoying the amount of hops in this fresh bottle, and the alcohol doesnt come through much at all compared to the nose. More malts and oak finish it out.

M/D - Medium to full body with a little too much carbonation for me. Drinkability is great since I love hoppy barleywines and barrel aging!

This is one of the better HotD beers Ive had. Im really glad I have another one I can hold on to and see what happens.

09 12 oz bottle pours rich amber with minimal head into a snifter.  Aroma of wet oak wood chips, caramel malts, sour lactose, bit of hop bitterness, dried bananas, apricots.  Upfront caramel malts quickly give way to an odd lactose sourness.  Oak flavor is definitely present in full.. really weird character.  Dried fruits, vanilla, finishes sweet and sour.  Silky smooth mouthfeel with low carbonation, full bodied.  Definitely an odd one and left me very confused, but pleased.

The lemony vanilla aroma from the oak barrels is perfect. The appearance is ruby yellow light amber with a small but nice head. The flavor is so smooth it is hard to believe it is a barley wine. It is slightly sweet like hints from the barley wine, but easy on the palate.

Are you a dog lover? Yeah, me too. In fact, I especially love my dogs when they are just about at cellar temperature and demanding my immediate quaffing attentions. Oh, wait. Are we talking about two different kinds of dogs? Im talking about the bottled kind. You know, the ones from Hair of the Dog Brewery out of Portland, Oregon. Probably their most famous pooch is the Hair of the Dog Fred which, on his own is one fabulous standard Barleywine, but add a little bit of wood, a sprinkle of bottle-conditioning, and you suddenly have a rare breed on your hands. If you must give him a name, as all good dogs need a good name, I would call mine the Hair of the Dog Fred From the Wood. Dont like it? Tough; I think its got a nice ring to it.


Dirty orange and desperately in need of a bath, he has a splattering of bubbly froth which splashes against the sides of my glass with nary a rhyme nor a reason. Its quite the sticky stuff too, lingering from first quaff to last. A big whiff of his nose finishes with a prominent hit of alcohol in the back. Not enough to burn any nose hairs, but certainly enough to gather my full attentions. Oranges steeped in booze then stewed slowly over a low heat permeates his nose while in the background mingle faint notes of baled hay, sprouted grains, and sweet orange marmalade spread over toasted bread. This is definitely going to be one bruiser of a dog, or at least, thats how he appears at the moment. My first sip is sweeter than I anticipated with homemade marmalade taking center stage. I take a generous dab and spread it over golden toasted bread while cinnamon sugar with a touch of nutmeg awaits their fair sprinkling. While I bite into that, boozy fruits rush my senses and latch firmly onto my palate. While her first impressions are sweet, toasty, and a bit spiced, her middle and finish are all about the finest oranges steeped and stewed in booze. There is no burn, just pleasantly permeating warmth with a nice addition of fresh peaches to the stewed oranges. Dry spices and warmth linger long in my breath as my mouth thirsts for more. Sawdust flitters in and out of the background; just enough wood to remind me of where Fred has been lately. Hair of the Dog Fred From the Wood was exquisitely un-complex which made for all that more of an enjoyable quaffing session.


I spent a long time with this beer, not so much to try and find more aromas and flavors than were actually there, but because it was most heavy, most warm, and most satisfying. A sipper to be sure, Id love to pair this beer as an after-dinner aperitif to enjoy with some fresh cheesecake with fresh orange-peach marmalade drizzled atop.

Hazy dark apricot pour with a thin white head.  Aroma is delicious citrus, vanilla wood, boozey warmth, orange, caramel malt creaminess.  Flavor is sweet creamy vanilla and orange citrus that tingles the palate.  the middle is sweet caramel and some fruitiness.  Finish is exquisite, a tartness that is delightfully woody.  I love the tart finish to this beer that obviously is a result of the barrel aging. Simply a revelation.

Hazy nectar pour with a thin white head. Aroma is bready caramel with lots of fruity esters, oak, orange, and vinous booze. Flavor holds an excellent balance of super sweet caramel, vanilla oak, tart orange nectar, angelfood cake dough, and sweet grape. Palate is very thick, rich, silky, velvety, and supple. Quite fulfilling. Super unique and well put together in all its facets a world class sipper.

Murky peach colored pour with a minimal head. Aroma is very nice; definite citrus hop,with grapefruit and orange peel, along with caramelized sugars, oak, and brandy. Flavor is wondrous; perfect combination of citrus hop, oak and booze, and sweet caramel malt. There is also a beautiful tartness from the barrels at the finish, which contributes marvelously to the overall palate impression; one could almost think theres a pinch of brett in this beer. 10% is clearly there, but welcomed. Excellent barleywine.

Bottle. 2008 edition. Bit hazy deep golden with a big thick off white head. The aroma is dried fruit like prune and dates, oak, vanilla, barley, floral hops, dark molasse, bread, caramel and sweets. The flavour is a powerful mix of sweet malt, caramel, bourbon-like sweet alcohol, vanilla, oak, sweet tobacco, dried fruit and hops. Sweet and complex and oh so yummy. Creamy textured. A very nice Barley indeed!

Bottled 12 Floz. Pale beige creamy head. Flowery soft nose. Soft taste with raisins and hints of oak. At the end hoppiness. Tasty wellbalanced beer with suitable hoppiness. Mild vanilla hints. Soft creaminess.

Pours a clear medium orange with a finger of frothy, bubbly tan head. Aroma is quite sour. Some tart cherries, a hint of vinegar, sweet vanilla butterscotch or caramel, wood, some barnyard funk, dried light fruits, perhaps pineapple, a hint of alcohol. Taste is fairly sweet, with a tangy, sour finish, like dried apricots, pineapples and cherries mixed with vanilla fudge or vanilla sauce with brown sugar and some cheese. Some heat in the finish. Medium to thick body, carbonation is sparse, but whats there is quite sharp, making it strangely refreshing. Tongue is somewhat brazed after a big sip, so this is pretty intense stuff. Definitely some good stuff right here, quite different from what I had expected.

2009 vintage. Bottle served in a snifter. Murky burnt orange in color with a short off-white head. What lies beneath? Layers upon layers of sweet malt on the nose: wood, dried fruit, vanilla, raisin, caramel, cheese, and prunes. Wow! Immense flavors and a beautiful mouthfeel. Rich, Full, Thick, Creamy. . . All Caps. Elements of chocolate, candied dates, nuts, and citrus. This could be dessert. A tinge of alcohol and light bitterness on the long, sticky finish. Complex to the core.
A very complex beer.  Nice white head orangey gold.  Hints of orange wood.  A farmhouse aroma.  Explanation doesnt do justice, had it last night.  Excellent.

2009 bottle from bvc. Red orange, hazy pour into a de paas snifter. Lots of sweetness in the nose, unexpected for the wood aging, but not overpowering at all. Dried apricot, melon, and the wet, woody smell lingering in the back. Really nice. Taste is the dried fruit and some tropical lightly funky fruit (papaya?), then a nice balancing toffee/tootsie roll thing, all wrapped up by the oaky, vinous flavor (like a smoky Pinot Noir). A little warmer, and I swear there are fig newtons in here (in a good way). A touch of hop bitterness finishes. Not entirely my thing normally, but this is a really, really well done beer. Thanks, B.

2008 bottle shared by shawnm213- thanks again, Shawn!  Pours a red-orange color with creamy off-white head.  The aroma is fruity, with raisin, melon, plum, nectar, honey, caramel, oak, vanilla, and alcohol- really great.  Flavor is caramel, mixed fruits that arent as easily distinguishable as in the aroma, oak, honey, and warming alcohol.  Agree with Shawn that this could use some more time to mellow, as the fruity alcohol still dominated.  Medium-full bodied, with a sweet, boozy aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2009 2008 bottle.   Luckily recived this from multiple people-  from ditmier, juiceisloose, and wavers1-  thanks guys!   Pours a dark golden orange with red highlights.  beautiful frothy beige head with rediculous lace.  Aroma of  honey, mellons, fruits, wood, plum, pineapple.  all kinds of fruits up in here.  a little melony booze as well.  Flavor is melon, booze, pear, plum, burnt rubber, oak.  still a bit hot.  this could use some more age on it.  the melon booze was a little too much.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2012 17th August 2008. Cloudy amber brown beer with a woody nose. Rich almost salty barleywine underpins sweet oak and vanilla. A soft palate with medium dryness. Some grapefruit hop at the end. Complex and moorish. Original rating 3.821st November 2009Hazy dark amber beer. Thick frothy white head. Oaky vanilla nose. Light frothy palate. Light creamy vanilla oak start. Sweet creamy mid with mellow but fruity hops which contrast nicely with the oaky sweetness. Finishes frothy and soft with some peppery spice. Slightly bitter aftertaste. A wonderful medley of top class beer flavours!

2008.  Bottle from scrizz.  Wow.  Orange-amber color with a pencil thin head thats short lived.  Complex aroma with cherry, candi sugar, toffee, caramel, plums, oak.  The flavors are incredibly smooth; tobacco, oak, sweet toffee, caramel, candy apples.  A controlled hoppy spiciness in the finish thats a perfect compliment to the sweet flavors.  This is a damn fine beer.  Thanks Clint!

12oz bottle, 2008, thanks to Beerlando. Pours golden with a frothy white head, leaves a little lacing. This is just divine. Nose is toffee, soft oak and vanilla, hints of caramel and soft hints of tropical fruits. The flavor is out of this world. Sweet toffee, caramel, notes of passion fruits, soft oaky vanilla, some nice tannins and a soft booziness. Nice backing bitterness. Lush and balanced for such a big beer.

12 fl. oz bottle. Huge, fluffy yellowish head. Dark, brownish amber body. Smells deliciously sweet; an intense, refined, toffee-/caramell-sweetness. Also a scent of vinous fruitiness, fresh hops,  and subtle wooden note. Taste has a strong caramelly malt profile, evenly balanced by a bold hop bitterness, with lots of fruits and pine.  A rounded and subtle oakiness in the backbone. Notes of mild spices, alcohol and vanilla. Big-bodied and creamy in the mouth. Lasting hoppy and malty finish. Both balanced and edgy, refined and powerfull. Great stuff.

2008 vintage.

Hazy orange/amber color with a stylish ivory-colored big and hard head that slowly settles into some chunky lacings. A really good looking beer.

Lots and lots of wonderful aromas of fresh/new oak barrels, very clean and well defined. Plenty of vanilla, Some notes of grassy and spicy hops. Candy. Perhaps a hint of fruit. A hint of alcohol.

A wonderful taste of fresh/new oak-barrels with big notes of vanilla. A tasty semi-sweet malty backbone beneath the oak character. The taste is quite sweet actually. Candy. Honey? Light hop aromas in the mouth. The finish is pleasant with a nice bitterness to it, some alcohol and mild phenols, and some spicy hops.

Medium body with a very smooth texture.

I really liked this one. A very refined and sophisticated character, yet with plenty of edginess to make things interesting. The aromas of fresh oak barrels in this one are amazing.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)
bottle, via trade with scrizz, golden orange color with still head, aroma of mandarin oranges, pineapple, passion fruit, flavors of caramel, honey, honeydew melon, oaky chardonnay, great finish

Poured from the amazing brew master Alan Sprint at HOTD. Poured dark red with a Small white head. Nose was sweet with a small amount of pine, and honey and caramel. Palette was smooth and sticky. Taste was oak, vanilla, citrus,  caramel and sweet malts. This was an amazing brew. Thanks again Alan. HOTD has always been among my favorite breweries but after visiting it truly became #1. I strongly recommend stopping by.

12oz 2008 bottle.  Nice orangish dark golden with small halo white head.  Nose is sweet...honey and light caramel with some spiciness with earthy oak notes but almost some quality irish whiskey going on.  Sticky and smooth on the palate with some tight snappy carbonation.  Sweet, but not overly.  Honey, vanilla notes, light apricot.  Hints of oak and a touch of tobacco with some alcohol warming.  I am not sure why I dont but more of this beer...I guess I will need to rectify that Nov 14th.

Flaske: Kæmpe skumhoved på en uklar orange øl. Virkelig stærk duft af bourbon karamel. Smagen er fantastisk koncentreret med store mængder bourbon og en god del alkohol. Hvis jeg var mere vild med bourbon er dette klart en potentiel 5.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
[vintage 2007]
Pours clear dark red with a great, creamy, off-white head. Aroma has cellar, prunes, red apples, oak, vinious, peach, caramel and lightly roasted. Low carbonation, wonderful oily mouthfeel. Really impressive. Flavour is initially quite sweet, lots of toasted caramel, light roasted, some tobacco, prunes, vanilla, oak, light tartness. Incredibly well-balanced between bitterness, sweetness and oaky tartness. Long, long lingering aftertaste that adds chocolate, pine and apples.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2010 2009 batch. 12oz bottle thanks to Sparky27 for hooking me up with this one. Pours dark orange with golden edges and small off-white head. Aroma is oak, vanilla, caramel, citrus and some booze. Flavor is oak, vanilla, citrus, grapes, caramel, sweet malt, and light hops. Finishes sweet with very light alcohol burn. Really great mouthfeel and perfect carbonation for a BA barley wine. I liked regular Fred quite a bit, but this version is much better. The oak barrels really add a nice complexity. It doesnt  have some of the cloying sweetness regular Fred has. This is a really good beer. Cheers HOTD.
Re-rate: Was able to get my hands on a couple of bottles of the original batch from rooftoprogue. Has held up unbelievably well. Aroma is unbelievable. Flavor has perfect balance of oak, caramel, vanilla, and alcohol.  Has also picked up a bit of sherry as well. Damn good beer.

Smells of vanilla, apple, grapefruit, pineapple and coconut.  Tastes of apricot, grapes, and prune.  This is one excellent barley wine, worlds of character, its barley wine with an added richness, which seems crazy or over the top in concept but it works!  This ones a winner.

Huge thanks to savvy1982 for the share of this great beer! Pours a transparent burnt orange with a small white head. The aroma is bright, fresh, and full of oak. Vanilla, coconut, oranges, flowers, toast, and white grapes. Tastes very similar to the nose. Very intense and complex. Buttery mouth feel. Very, very good!

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2010 2009 bottle recheck wow this is still a tremendous beer. so well crafted in its huge strength strength but all the subtleties still shine. not quite as funked as the 08 bottle more towards the barley wine side. not sure where I got all the citrus in the last bottle though.

2008 bottle rating #900! poured an orange amber in color with a thin wisp of white foam on the surface. aroma has sour funky citrus, tart grapefruit, light oak, sweet bourbon, white grape, and a nice fully fermented honey like sweetness. absolutely amazing aromas coming out of this glass. mouth feel is fairly rich in a creamy way and the carbonation is on the low side. flavor comes across picking up on the malts, bitter citrus, oak, caramel, grapefruit skin, sweetness, and a nice alcohol warming. this is by far the best barley wine I have tried, plenty of citrus, barrel aged, nice sourness, and perfect sweetness. Wow!

Pours with a golden orange body topped by a thick head with a good amount of lacing.  Its sweet and malty with nice citrusy notes as well as pleasing vanilla/bourbon notes.  Full bodied and smooth yet warming.

2008 batch poured from Bottle into Tulip glass.

Pours a murky orange color that radiates in the glass and has a pillowing two fingers of head that is slow to dissolve. The aroma is sweet citrus peel, yeast, vanilla and caramel. The flavor has sweet malt and grapefruit upfront and is accompanied by toffee, vanilla and finishes sweet and boozy. It has a creamy full body and makes it a nice sipper. Very enjoyable beer. Highly quaffable and deliciously decadent.

Bottled. Auction. Cloudy Amber pour with thin white head. Sweet malt and oak aroma with hints of toffee and vanilla. The taste matches the aroma perfectly the only difference is a mild hop presence. Medium body and easy carbonation makes this on a perfect blend that goes down easy.

Draught at the brewery. Thanks, Alan. 
Big oak/vanilla flavors. Fabulously smooth and slightly sour. Very nice, though maybe the oak was a bit overpowering.

bottle.  pours a hazy, dark orange with a thin, off-white head which dissipated quickly.  Nose of fermented citrus with caramel and some wood.  Taste is fermented fruit, caramel, vanilla, honey and some wood.  Mouthfeel is medium and sticky.  Very nice.
This ale hits like a winter swell; it has a compound dark fruit and malt aroma with an extraordinary and well balance palate. Nutritious and Delicious.

This is from two different tastings of this. Hazy dark orange pour with virtually no head. Grapefruit, vanilla and barrel aroma, wow that is good. Big grapefruit hops, medium malt thickness that really lets the citrus stand out. Nice barrel/vanilla notes great balance of bitter and sweet. Just an outstanding brew.

2008 vintage.  Pours an almost brown orange with super thick off-white head, tons of lacing.  Aroma of dulled hops, mostly citrus, molasses, candy sugar, dried fruits, caramel and a nice oak backbone.  Flavor matches well and I think the oak is a nice complement to the original product, despite apparently dulling the hops some.  Everything comes together nicely and makes for a wonderful brew.  Alcohol warmth obvious, but not dominant.  This is a sipper my friend.  Thanks HotD!

This was sold to me at the brewery. Very happy to try this one. In fact, I cant believe I was able to purchase a 12 oz. bottle of this. Translucent dark orange with a brown hue. Thin head sitting on top. Sweet malty/sugary wood aroma. Very fruity slightly citrus. Fairly complex aroma. Slight citrus aroma, with a very sweet candy/sugar flavor. Nice wood touch with some citrus to finish it out. I am surprised to swee how well the citrus and wood stand out. VERY smooth delicious beer. I am overwhelmed, seeing I have tried almost 5 Hair of the Dog beers in less than 2 days!

Poured from 12oz bottle into Duvel tulip.

A - Golden color, mirky, with a small amount of white head that quickly vanishes leaving a white ring around the edge of the glass. 

S - Lots of sweet cirtus, mandarin oranges, tangerines, and mango notes. 

T - Similar to the nose, I get sweet citrus flavors. Some alcohol burn in the way down, but I think the 10% is hidden pretty well on this beer (as good as you can hide 10%). Bitterness on the end mixed with some alcohol burn.

M - very rich, creamy, medium in body. Slight carbonation, I think it could use a bit more. 

D - Not really digging this one.

Thanks to richlikebeer for this beauty. Batch 64. Pours a brown color with a medium white head. Has a great wood and carmel smell. Taste of wood, caramel with a little sweet finish. Very well blended in the flavor

Thank you richlikebeer.  This is special.  Slightly off-white foamy head.  Caramel-brown color.  Aroma of caramel, oak, vanilla, and honey.  Flavor of caramel, vanilla, honey, and a touch of oak.  Balance is just exceptional.

12oz bottle (2008) Pours burnt orange with a huge tan head that lasted for quite some time, nice lace left behind. Aroma is huge burnt oak, vanilla, bread, dark fruit and malt. Flavor is very much the same, burnt oak , vanilla, honey,   caramel malt, finish is woody, honey and warming alcohol. Medium body and sticky, very nice beer! I wish I had another.

12oz bottle as a generous extra, Cliff or Brendan I think!  Pours a cloudy dark gold with a medium head.  Flowery, caramel bouquet.  Sweet with a rosy flavor, vanilla, a little oak.  Not dry or balanced enough, just too much sweet malt, kind of overbearing.

[Bottle] Pours a nice oaky brown with a fairly large, but not nearly as large as the regular version, head. Aroma is loaded with oak, lots of coconut and vanilla, and the base beer is definitely still there as well. Flavor matches the aroma very well, a nice graininess, alcohol is present, but nice and warming, and the oak really accentuates the malt sweetness and leaves some toastiness and tannins on the finish.

Rating #1400.  2008 bottle.  Dark brown-orange, big loose off white foam.  Aroma of charred oak, caramels, vanilla, bready, sweet malts.  Taste is sweet, but with a high carbonation, caramel, charred oak barrel, light vanilla, more caramelized malt, brown sugar, woody, alcohol finish.

Deep amber colour with a small beige head. Aroma is pure candy, vanilla, oak and dark sweet fruit. Mouthfeel is slick, the body is medium full with flavours of sweet candy, fruit, light oak, liqour and a small fruity bitterness. Very well composed and drinkable.

Bottle shared by juiceisloose @ otakudens Vero Beach Throwdown. Pours cloudy caramel color with almost nonexistent head. Aromas of bread dough, vanilla and alcohol. Sweet caramel and dough flavors with some wood and vanilla. Slight alcohol burn. Medium to full body with soft carbonation and a sticky mouthfeel.

Bottle...  Poured burnt orange with a thin white head.  Spiced, boozy, oaky and grainy aroma.  Thick, chewy palate with flavors of tea leafs, apple-like fruits and a candy sweetness like caramel, toffee, or butterscotch which played off the malt nicely.  A nice bitter, hop finish with spices and cloves.  Amazingly smooth and not too hot for 10%.

07 bottle thanks to ditmier!Opaque orange-amber, frothy cream head with lots of lacing. Lots of vanilla and oak from the barrel, also minor hop and honey. Flavor is similar but shows more tea, earth, and hop notes, still very sweet though. Moderate body. I wish there was more going on here, at least more that is not buried under the sweetness.

Bottle. Aromas are dominated by wood and leather and somehow it reminded me of my old math library at the University of Goettingen? Flavors are great, the sweetness that is perhaps too present in the regular Fred ids offset by this oaky, woodsy flavor. The alcohol is hidden very well and the beer goes down very smoothly.
Poured golden amber @RBSG09 Grand Tasting, caramel, dark fruits, wood, vanilla, little alcohol.

Very Fred in aroma, initial taste and middle taste. More oaky in initial aroma and flavor than fred. Same neutral honey middle. Understated oaky honey finish. Overall very tasty and smoother tasting but less complex than lesser brethren. Preferred. In interest of complexity I would go with Fred. In interest of taste, Fred of the wood. Fred of the wood is overall a better tasting smoother beer.

12 oz bottle.  Clear gold pour, slightly orange tinge, thin white head.  Caramel malt, sweet fruit, raisin, vanilla, oak, and some musty malts.  Hints of tabacco and cherries.  Some alcohol pressence.  Complex and really tasty, I am not to much in the mood for it though, its hot in here haha (and just got warmer).

Bottle courtesy of Sparky27.  Wow.  Poured a hazy copper color with a thin off-white head.  Huge sheets of lace left on the glass.    Aroma is boozy caramel, oak, rasin, and phenols.  Full bodied with lots of tongue prickling alcohol and a smooth, almost oily, rounded mouthfeel.  Carbonation is lively.  Sweet alcoholic flavor with lots of wood notes, dark fruit, tobacco, and vanilla.  Finishes hoppy with lots of warming alcohol.  Excellent!

2008 bottle. Pours a hazy, dark orange body topped by a small, foamy white head that settles to a thin film. The aroma is nice and shows hints of sweet fruits, toasted caramel, toffee, wood, and vanilla. The flavor shows more of the same with sweet, dark fruits, caramel, and wood. Some cherries start to push through along with some vanilla cream. Some citrusy hops add just enough bitterness on the backend. Medium-full bodied and very smooth with a lengthy sweet finish and a touch of heat. Really nice stuff here. HOTD never seems to fail.

12 oz Bottle ,thanks to kosko20 .
A nice muddy golden orange color body, with a huge foamy off white head that lasts for ever, medium carbonation, tuns of lacing and sheeting. Aroma if lots of oak , sweet malt, tobacco ,and apple skins .  Favor is out of this world Huge caamel malt , sweet cherry, vanilla, honey ,nuts and  hint of alcohol , sticky mouthfeel but the carbonation seems to clean the palate between sips, Full body , balenced , very complex and everchanging flavors and aromas . Probably the best beer I have had to date.

Bottle thanks to Cletus.  Rating number 600.  Shared this with my dad on fathers day.  Pours a hazy brown with a large white head.  Big caramel, malt, vanilla, and a touch of smoke and wood, with a touch of alcohol.  Medium to thick body.  Very deep dark fruit, plums and prunes, Finishes with a nice light bitterness and some dry wood notes.  Pretty well balanced.  Im still not a huge barley wine fan, but this one is pretty decent.  Sadly, no one else liked it.  Oh well, more for me.

@Pilsner Petes East Coast Gathering-12oz bottle-pours a white ring for a head and cloudy orange color.  Aroma is medium malt/grain/wood, medium fruit, yeast, vanilla, spice hops.  Taste is medium malt/grain/wood, medium fruit-orange rind, yeast, vanilla, spice hops-bitter.  Interesting.  Thanks malrubius for sharing, even after my dooh!

Bottle at DLD 09, thanks to Drewbeerme.  Slightly hazy amber with medium beige head.  ARoma is ver bourbon forward with caramel, sweetness, some age and vanilla.  Flavor is vanilla, cherry, big bursting fruit, real tasty, grapey, yeast, age, real nice.  Mesium body with slight carbonation.  Real tasty, solid, could drink a lot of it.

330ml bottle (Olutkellari, Helsinki) - shared with a couple of olutopas dudes - thanks!
Hazy copper, not poured clear alas, and a healthy head. RIch buttery toffee aroma. Diacetyl by the tonne. Fortunately diacetyl doesnt turn me off a beer. Smooth body; in fact its not smooth, its slimy. That could be the yeast. Vanilla and buttery malt loaf in the mouth - did I mention diacetyl? Huge hoppy bite, but within acceptable limits. Pretty OK, but the slimy palate it too much. Sticks my lips together with sugars. The sugars dont cover the alcohol either - this smelt and tasted as if it was well over 10%. Great if you like diacetyl, sugar and booze.

Fathers Day present come early. Couldnt wait more than one day to open this. First taste is of caramel and cherry. Let me stop and look at this beer. Not very dark. Second taste is some kind of chocolate mixed with cherry. Maybe some maple syrup. Vanilla. There is oak in the flavor - like what one would say about a wine. Wow. Much different than what I was expecting...thought it would be dark and intense, but it is full of fruit and maple. Something else is in there that I cannot put my finger on. Very lovely beer.

Bottle.  Pours a brownish gold with a massive head.  Aromas are vaguely bready with a little tanginess to it.  Flavor is a fruit bowl with pears, white grape juice and some oak.  Flavor is very sweet and fruity as predicted by the nose.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle shared by MrBunn. Orangey red pour, big fluffy head. Aroma is all bread with a touch of maple or oak. Not sure of this bottle. Boozy caramel flavors....wood notes are present. Lots of fruit floats in and out of the flavor. Very different, and not quite what I expected. Alcohol is a little dominating in the finish, but its still fairly smooth and all right.

355 ml bottle brewed in 2008. Reddish to dark orange colour with a whitish head. The oak is present in the aroma along with some vanilla and caramel. The taste is dominated with toffee-like sweetness with hints of fruitiness and oak. Notes of warming alcohol also present. Aftertaste includes elements of oak, malts and a bit of hops. The bottle was served way too chilled, which obviously affected the taste.

2008 vintage.
Appearance  Pours a glowing golden color with a tiny quarter finger head that disappears quickly and leaves a tiny ring clinging on for dear life around the edge of the glass. When held up to the glass this is a slightly hazy golden orange hue. 

Smell  Hints of Belgian yeast, oak, and pale malts. There is a fruitiness to it that I cant put my finger on.

Taste  Slight tinge of hops surrounded by a blast of oaky, fruity malts. Some grapes and cherries dance together and meld well. Some raisins are also doing their thing in there. This is too damn complex for me to get everything.

Mouthfeel  There is a slight tingle from the low carbonation, perfect for this beer. This feels very syrupy without being too thick. Coats the mouth well and sticks around to let you indulge in the complex flavor profiles. 

Drinkability  Awesome beer, a definite sipper though. This is one of those beers you really only want to drink one of because it is so damn complex and rich in flavor.

12oz. batch 64. Pour is dark amber with a sticky off white head. Aromas of oak, warming alcohol, vanilla, and caramel. Flavor is downright smooth! Oak, vanilla, sweet fruits, and finishing with a small amount of alcohol. Just sipping on this guy is great. It also got much better as it warmed.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Pours a dark golden colour with a big white sturdy head, lacing is superb .. . smell is of sweet maple, light alcoholic wood, sherry, vanilla, oak .. . 1-1 at the half, usa vs hon ... .. super smooth, medium to full sweetness but the barrel aging does a nice job of dancing with the sweetness .. . touch of bitterness that just works, good dog! .. . HotD, pelo del perro .. lacing really is fantastic, The deaf man would weep for the blind man. .. USA USA USA!!! .. . no alcohol burn detected, quite amazing it that aspect! .. . fruity and light oak, maple and magic tastes.. a true classic barrel aged beer!

Deep reddish brown colour, mediumsized beige creamy head. Aroma is fruity, sugary, alcoholic and some hints of some nectary and vanilllaish notes. Flavour is quite sweet nectary and wooden notes along with vanilla, alcohol and some nice fruity notes.

Found a 2007 bottle of this at Woodstock Deli in Portland.  Colour... dark orange. Nose... fresh marmalade and Valencia skins with a hint a treacle. Palate... funk up front and then the barrel with lots o oak and burnt sugar and a nicely loooooooong cloying finish.

2008 bottle acquired via trade.  Hazy medium-brown color with a small off-white head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malt, oak/barrel notes, fruit, and a Bretty tartness/funk.  Flavor is complex and great with funky tartness balancing the sweet caramel malt, citrus, apricot, tobacco, whiskey, and vanilla.  Hops mostly faded after one year in the bottle.  Really smooth and creamy on the palate.  Like regular Fred overall with barrel flavors, tartness, and subtle fruit notes more pronounced.  Looking forward to the 2009 which I also received in the trade.

(Bottle, 0.355 l, at Olutkellari Helsinki on 2009-06-01) Hazy and brown. Small white head. Hops, oak and whisky in aroma. Full bodied and dry palate with little carbonation. Wood, raisin, whisky, vanilla, apricots, fruitiness, sweetness, hops and bitterness in taste. Wood, malts and bitterness in aftertaste. The inital almost too strong wood aroma softens after a while.

Consumed at Petes spring gathering. Purs lighter in color than I excpected it would. Great aroma of candy apple, brown sugar.. flavor is similar, with the addition of a little bit of sourness and funk.
Pours out a dark golden color with little to no head. Smells as great as it tastes.. Taste is fruity and woody and funky. Sticky sweet and complex. A very original brew.

Source:  12 oz bottle, batch 64, in a trade with Suttree.  Thanks! Glass: Snifter. Appearance:Ruddy brown pour with a one finger tan head.  Aroma:  Cherries, oak, vanilla and some tobacco, with sweet malt.   Flavor: Lots of oak, vanilla and sour cherries.  Hints of tobacco.  Mild bitter finish. Palate:  Full bodied with soft carbonation and a chewy, mouthfeel.Overall:  This was all I had expected.  Excellent beer that aged nicely.  Wish I had more!

Big thanks to BrewDad for this one. 2007 done in side-by-side with original Fred 73. This one pours a bit deeper cloudy orange with a very thin persistent head. Lots of persistent bubbling.  Aroma is apricots, rock candy, distant citrus hops, and a nice woody background.  Smells sweeter than the Original Fred.  Flavor is malty and rock candy up front.  Then the wood kicks in. The wood lingers as the hop flavors come and go.  First pine hops, then citrus.  Nice sticky mouthfeel. After a while of savoring the finish, all of the flavors of the Original Fred come flooding in: black pepper, citurs hops, a slight alcohol burn and grapefruit.  The finish really is delightful, it just lasts and lasts. its like having the original Fred in your mouth for 2 minutes.  I do not think I could pick a favorite. The original is more a daytime/summer beer that drink very smoothly.  This one is more of a night/autumn sipper but still not heavy.
Much like regular Fred, this beer is hard to describe. Very fruity and malty sweet yet tangy. Really sweet, but also dries nicely. Lots going on but I cant quite describe it all. Odd fruits.
Pours a golden caramel with a thin head.  Aroma is a fruity sour-ish smell.  Flavor is really sweet with some oak.  Its an odd beer.  Some wine notes as well.  I just like this beer.

Golden pour with a thin white head. Nice lacing. Aroma of mildly sour star fruit, perhaps a hint of cumquat, caramel, mild bourbon. Flavor is caramel, maple candy, wood, star fruit. Gets better as it warms. Solid mouthfeel. Very good beer.

Big thanks to vwcraig for sending this 2007 my way as part of a recent trade. I have had Fred and liked it a lot so I am anticipating fftw. This beer was a tad darker than Fred but still sorta golden until the last dregs went in which turned it a ruby, cloudy color. The smell is like whiskey or bourbon, strong alcohol, wow! I dont drink whiskey or bourbon but I love the smell of this beer. Surely this was not aged in plain oak barrels, if it was, huzzah. Wow, the taste is woody! Woody and also slightly bitter hoppiness at the end. This does not taste like the Fred I had last year at all. This is very good but is a slow sipper due to the strength of the flavor. Im sure this stuff is also pretty potent as far as ABV goes. Very nice beer but I should have shared it with a friend :( .

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-08-2008 03:06:08

2008.  I get some cider vinegar here.  Makes me nervous.  At least it smells like the good stuff.  Gentle gold, small white head.  Sweet and still in the mouth, its presence is very wine-like with notes of toasted oak and muscat grapes.  Theres a hint to a sourness and im worried about this beers future.  Will approach again later.
Poured amber with a white head. Aroma of alcohol with a hint of caramel. Flavor was alcohol with some fruit and toffee.

Sampled at Dark Lord Day 09, couldnt believe this was sitting on the table. Sweet, oaky aroma with a bit of alcohol. Flavor is easily one of the most complex barley wines  Ive ever had. Caramel, oak , vanilla, bourbon. Very sweet, yet  off set by the barrel. Excellent, so awesome I got to try this one.

Thanks to jonathaL7890 for this brew

Pours a one finger head

Nose- Alcohol, perfumey, maple, cherries.

Appearance cloudy brownish/coppery

Mouthfeel I get some sweetness up front then its warmed by the alcohol.

Taste- Tobacco, toffee, maple syrup, slight grapefruit. alcohol shows up in the end

This beer is not one of my favorites. It might could benefit from age. I will not seek this beer out again.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle. High creamy and lasting white head. Clear amber body. Heavy barley malt hops grass hay fruit aroma. Fruity sweet hoppy spicy alcohol wood whisky flavor. Low carbonation. Long aftertaste.

0.355 l bottle at Oluthuone Esplanadi, Tampere. Hazy golden to copper color with big fluffy head. Thick aroma with toffee, lemony american hops, nuts, vanilla and raisins. Thick bittersweet, toffeish, nutty and hoppy flavor with vanilla, oak, licorice and madeira wine. Very full bodied, very warming and very complex.

12oz bottle thanks to Oscar at The Red.   Dark gold with an off-white head.   The aroma is a spicy mix of hops and oak with light yeasty dough and caramel coming through as well.   The flavor has a nice honey and caramel malt sweetness with a spicy, herbal, oaky and hoppy balance.   Very smooth and full texture.   The oak throws a big layer of complexity at you but blends well with the rest of the beer.   Pretty cool stuff that makes me really want to get to my bottle of the regular version now.

An unexpected gift from Oscar at The Red in Santa Cruz. Pours a hazy golden color with a creamy tan head. Aroma is caramel with overripe stone fruits. Flavor is pineapples, caramel, tannic wood, dark fruit, and peppery alcohol. Nice complexity. Full mouthfeel with good carbonation. Finish is dry and woody.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2009 Bottle via trade...a big thanks to Hannont (and maybe one from Hopdog too?)!  Finally getting off my ass and reviewing some beers instead of writing notes for another rainy day.  Pours a very ruddy brown with a heavy level of carbonation and a decent single-finger head that settles slowly with good lacing.  Aroma is a beautiful meld of a fruity, candy sweetness and a bold oak note, with the sweetness winning the battle...very engaging!  Flavor is, well, damn near amazing...glad I popped this one out of my newly organized cellar to get back to rating!  Heavy on roasty, caramel malts, dark fruit (raisiny), brown sugar, oak/tannins, vanilla, a slight note of tobacco, with a heavy, but enjoyable dose of booze at the end.  Finishes with a combination of very sweet, sugary malt and a slight hop bitterness...very unique in the finish.  Palate is a definite five...lively carbonation yet silky smooth...this is one of those rare beers I didnt even need to think about what to rate the palate.  Have I really been away from beer this long to where Im hyping this more than I should?  I dont think so...this is one fine beer and well deserving of the high ratings.  Near the best Ive ever had...

(Update, this was Batch 64 bottle)

I know I entered this rating but it seems to have disappeared so Ill have to wing it since I dont have my notes anymore.  This was a 12 oz. bottle I got in a trade.  Slightly hazy pour with a short head.  I remember the aroma be oaky and boozy.  I remember the flavor being oaky, boozy, smoky and sweet.  It had nice a mouthfeel and body to it with a nice warming alcohol/booze finish to it.

2006 bottle, batch 54.  Lightish golden orange with a slight haze and light grey to offwhite thin head. Sweet oaky nose.  Tobacco.  vinous.  Full malt, light vanilla.  Tannins and cherry.  Full creamy body with lower carbonation.  Full malt over oak.  Light smoke/tobacco.  Vinous oakiness.  Sweet malty leather balanced by fruitier astringency.  Fruity alcohol bite in the finish with lingering cigar.

Orange-amber in colour with a long lasting and creamy off-white head, excellent lacing.  The aroma is of oak, some butterscotch, quite sweet with some white sugar, scotch, some dark fruits.  The flavour is lightly bitter, some hops, caramel malts, rich apple pie, light alcohol.  Sweet and warming mouthfeel, medium body, moderate carbonation.  Finishes long, sweet and warming.
Nicely done.  This is an example of barrel aging that works for me.  Highly drinkable.
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with TheCheeseMan, thanks Dan.
Opened on November 29, 2008.
Vintage 2008.

Bottle:  Murky copper pour with no head.  Nose is really interesting...I seemed to get a big amount of raisins, citrus, coconut, vanilla and oak out of it.  Full bodied mouth feel...flavor was equally interesting with the aforementioned  notes all present with an emphasis on the citrus and oak.  Good beer.

12-oz. Pours deep murky coppery amber. Some thick white moussy film. Enormous nose of plums, oranges, and other dark fruit. Bold, stinging, carbonated attack (somewhat unusual given the BA). Super complex thick and oily mid-palate carrying fruits, vanilla, and no shortage whatsoever of oak. Incredibly dense orange pith flavors, especially in the clingy finish

Bottle received as a bonus from Cletus (youre incredibly generous man!)  Even with a slow poor, there was plenty of effervescent champaign like carbonation.  Wonderful dark/clear golden color with a herbal, yet sweet candi sugar aroma.  Flavor was amazingly complex; plum, raisins, tobacco, mellowed malts and finished like a good port.  Just an amazing beer.
