text:
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2008 Rerate.  12oz bottle, batch 64, courtesy of glkaiser.  Thanks a ton, Geoff!  Damn, this is good.  Pours a murky, orange brown color; fluffy, light tan head with fine-bubbled retention and lacing that coats the glass; a gorgeous pour.  Lovely, toasted oak and dried caramel presence in the aroma; soft, perfectly integrated barrel aging; inky, dried red fruits; impressively dense malt core, with orange and mineral bitterness present.  The hop character, which showed up as something of an afterthought in the aroma, is far more present in the mouth; full mouthfeel; dense, intense oranges coupled perfectly with toasted oakiness (vanilla, intricate wood presence); tons of fruitiness, with dried caramel (not really from oxidation; just solid malts); dense but well-attenuated, making for a very generous, drinkable beer; no alcohol to speak of.  Im going to be thoroughly disappointed when this bottle is empty.  Lengthy finish, showing toasted wood, breadiness, oak and oranges; a beautifully constructed barrel-aged barleywine.  Goddamn.
9.5.9.5.17=4.5.

RBSG 06, from the RB special release batch (courtesy of a fine citizen).  First pour from the bottle yields a gorgeous head with nice retention; oak, citrus on the nose.  Grapefruit notes, with a sweet malt core - vanilla, syrupy finish.  9.5.8.4.16=4.2.

Bottle. Batch 64. Pours a cloudy amber-brown with a tan head. I am smelling vanilla and oak off the first smells. Spicy smells, and alcohol. Flavor is very oak infused. It causes a dryness. Tasting also spicyness, vanilla, caramel.  A very nice hop finish to give a little bitterness. Very complex beer. Delightful to be able to add this to my cellar, will be a treat to age.

12oz bottle via trade with cbkschubert! - Thanks Craig! -  Batch 64 - Pours cloudy amber with a short tan head that didnt stay long.  Lots of oak in the nose, with some alcohol and tobacco as well as some spicy notes.  Flavor contains in the fore rich toffee and caramel but there at the back of each sip I found much oak, some spice, a touch of tobacco, some orange, and lots of alcohol.  There are also some grapefruit hops that can be found on the finish and really crash down on you at the back of the sip.  Lightly carbonated and full bodied.. This is quite complex and a delight to drink

(Bottle, batch 64)  Pours a cloudy burnt orange body with a small beige head.  Aroma of bourbon, toasted malt, and spices.  Flavor is dominated by woodiness and bourbon with some fruit and hops.  Enjoyable barley wine!

Pours slightly hazy orange-brown with a thick light-beige head that diminishes pretty quickly.  Aroma is complex with dark fruits, caramel, vanilla, oak, and maybe a little bit of cinnamon.  Hop aroma is low.  Flavor is much the same with maybe some candi sugar and apparent alcohol.  Hops are medium bitterness at the beginning and increase in intensity at the finish.  Oak is pretty subdued in flavor, but is apparent and does add some dryness.  Well balanced between malt and hops.  Pretty nice now, and should be even better in a year or two.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 Bottle.
Cloudy golden coloured with an off white head.
Aroma of fruits, vanilla, oak and wood.
Flavour of fruits, caramel, oak, vanilla and hops.

Batch 64.  Clear amber body with a thin, white head.  A big nose of vanilla, alcohol, caramel, coconut, oak, light toast and grain, and some mellow piney hop character.  Its really pretty sweet with subtle barrel-aging characteristics before a mild waft of hop resin.  The body is thick and smooth, with nice, tight carbonation on the tongue, making it a pleasure to imbibe.  The sweet nose translates will to the tastebuds.  The sweet caramel, vanilla, whole grains, coconut, light maple syrup and hint of toasted malt all add to an incredible malt complexity.  The oaky elements helps smooth out the considerable alcohol and the bitter piney and citric hop finish add a crisp smack of the lips derived from pure enjoyment.  My first impression of this was a touch disappointing.  However, given some time to just sit and sip, this quickly became a new favorite.  One of the better barrel-aged beers Ive had.  Im glad we did this as the introduction to this new series of beers!

12 oz. bottle, special RateBeer release 06/06.  Thanks to DarkElf for arranging the purchase of a case to split!  Pours a slightly hazed watermelon-amber color with a moderate off-white head and thick lace.  Aroma is dominated immediately by a strong oaky scent, sweet fruity malts become more evident as it warms, with raspberry and citrus and prominent alcohol.  Sweet and tart flavor, mellow woody malts, vanilla, brown sugar, orange, then an overwhelming blast of oaky tannins and alcohol, this effect diminishes as it warms from cellar to room temperature, making the experience a bit more pleasant overall.  Full body with nice creamy carbonation.  Its very apparent that this was aged in new oak, as the tannic, woody character seems dominant.  Right now I cant say that this was a great beer, it seems a bit unbalanced and dominated by the wood.  Of course, this is a newly released bottle, and I expect that the flavors will mellow and blend as this barley wine ages, so I look forward to re-rating this in a year or so.

The aroma is wonderful....big mix of bananas, toffee, wood and tobacco. The taste is quite complex...awesome. Same as the aroma, but with a very intense alcohol sweetness that I didnt pick up from the aroma. Amazingly thick and good carbonation. Bitter hops really come through at the end. This one should age quite well....

Batch 64 My first impression of the nose was of a white zinfandel, fading into a caramelly maltwith some spice a dark fruit notes. Red tinged amber color with a few tiny beige bubbles. Flavor shows the caramelly malts with a definte burbon flavor and a hoppy alcohol finish.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2006 From 12oz Bottle.  Pours a hazy honey apricot color with a creamy looking off-white head that quickly reduces to a thin film.  The color and texture of the beer is just beautiful to look at.  The arom a is restrained, but tantalizing nonetheless as a slightly tart incense of caramelized almonds, leek vegetalness, and semi-sweet sherry notes drift to my nostrils.  Some maple smoke and pear skins complete the bouquet.  Full bodied, lightly syrupy texture brings a delectable sweetened hop bath to warm the tongue.  A light spruce glaze coats the tongue initially with some sweet tangerine sauce.  I can see the sharp piney edges wearing off with age,which will make this beer even more fabulous for my personal taste bud preference.  This beer is nectar, combining so many of my favorite characteristcis into a neat 12oz package - delcious hop usage, slightly sweet malty notes that remind me of a pineapple glaze glistening atop a roasted ham, full bodied mouthfeel, breathtaking appearance, thoughtful aroma, a gentle tinge of oaky dryness, and a spicy character that I adore in many belgian ales.  I think I might be dangerously in love with this beer.  The finish is also greatly sustaining with more of the hoppy sweetness.  This will be an easy one for me to look forward to tasting in the years to come.

This is just a veritable monster.  Aroma unleashs itself out of the bottle and is an all out relentless assault from there.  Woody aroma, alcohol, and lots of fruit.  Hops are quite apparent, mouthfeel is quite syrupy, juicy and rich and layered in texture.  Bourbon, cherrywood, earth (undergrowth) and a citrusy hint of orange resin oil.  Interesting at best, but needs to lay down for awhile.

Bottle, batch 64.  Ruddy orange pour.  Aroma is fruity, with notes of allspice, cinnamon and bourbon.  Flavor is spicy with alcohol and sour bitterness and earthy undertones.  Mouthfeel is very nice, both crisp and heavy.  A bit unbalanced and too spiced for me.  The fruit and spice notes seem to be competing with each other, but both ultimately lose out to the taste of alcohol.  I agree that it would age well, some time to mellow and meld would make this beer much better.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2008 Poured a reddish amber color with a small, off white head that left nice, sticky, lacing on the glass.  Aroma of tons of dried fruits, candy, cherries, vanilla, and light bourbon.  Taste is of more sweet caramel, maple sugar, cherries, resin, tobacco, oak, and bourbon alcohol, with a light, citrus hop finish.  A bit sweet right now with pronounced alcohol... but I think it should age nicely.

Huge thanks to Goldtwins for sending me a bottle of this.  My cap was just fine.  The pour was turbid ruddy deep coppery/brown, with a 1-finger off-white head and amazingly long lasting lace sheets.  The aroma was intyense and complex, consisting of some funky tangerine, mango, oaky bourbon, black pepper, fine tobacco, and some caramel malt in the background.  The flavor....Whoa Nelly let me tell ya bout the flavor, Bob Griese!  At the start it was densely tropical and citrus fruit, with bold mango, tangerine, fig, and plum elements.  Then, the black pepper, oaky bourbon, tobacco, woody peaty malts, caramel malt, and hops kicked in, sort of in a cascading fashion but too quick to be noticed if you dont swallow slowly.  With every sip I took, I regretted that I was getting that much closer to the end of the bottle.  This beer is quite simply as good as it gets.  End of story.  Kudos to Alan Sprints for another balls to the wall beer.  The meek need not apply.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2007 Rate beer edition bottle coutesey of cbkschubert. Thanks Craig!
Odd but pleasant aroma. Very woodsy, tobacooy. Pours a thin head head that stays, very pale and cloudy. At first this is very oaky. Very oaky and with a smokey taste. Almost too much in the beginning. Aftering warming up it either mellows, grows on you, or both. Very satisfying brew. One for the colder months too be sipped. Right now it is in the low 50s in January, I could not pass this up. Very, very good brew. Cheers!

"So here in the oak barrels is the Fred from the Wood.  Im bottling it soon."  After hearing Alan describe this beer, I had to get some.  I was visiting HotD right before this barleywine aged in oak was bottled.  I feel lucky to kave known about this one before it was completely snached up.  Sampled from bottle.  Pours slightly cloudy copper with a thin, creamy white head and decent lacing.  Its average appearance does not foreshadow other attributes.  Aroma was bold, but not overpowering, with floral, citrus, berry and prune notes.  Earthy, woody, rich malt flavor with cigar tobacco, black pepper and nutmeg and/or all-spice.  Quite complex, but still very drinkable.  Viscous, smooth and warming.  An excellent beer by any standard.

12oz bottle.  Hazy body under a small white ehad.  Good lacing.  Lots of small bubbles lazily drift up the side of the snifter; mesmerizing to watch.  Honey/toffee sweetness along with floral perfume start the aroma with some peppery spice becoming apparent at the end.  Quite a lot going on in the flavor.  Up front orange blossom honey hits you the strongest and is followed by yeasty caramel, pollen, fresh-cut wood.  The finish lingers on crystal malt, light peppery alcohol, and more of that floral perfume.  Rich, almost syrupy mouthfeel thats well-offest by light tingly carbonation and the alcohol spice.  Im really looking forward to my 2nd bottle in two years - hopefully the alcohol will have calmed down letting the sweet malts come out.

Small, tight beaded tan head, retention is very good, lace is sticky, spotty and lasting. Hazy, gold/orange hued brew. Nose is wood and a touch of vanilla, licorice and a touch earthy. Body is med/full, prickly on the tongue, wood tannins? Creamy also, interesting. Lotsa wood flavors along with notes of playdough, ashes, whisky, fruit, some peach notes hiding in there with a smack of alcohol. Finish is dry, woody and light astringency. A very neat brew. I believe this brew will be pretty amazing with some age on it. The lumber is really in yer face right now but with some time to mellow out, this brew will be amazing! Now thats a B/A Barleywine! Many thanks to cbkschubert and jjpm74 for the trades!! Now i will be able to see how this puppy ages. Thanks guys!

RateBeer Edition  --  Huge thanks to Kinz for providing the bottles for our 3rd Richmond Gathering.  Deep orange-brown body, cloudy with a very minimal whte head.  Heavy oak aroma, with citrus and nuts in the aroma.  Great taste, light citrus, caramel with heavy oak flavoring.  A light spicy-nut ending.

Many thanks to jimmack and richlikebeer, both of whom brought some of this to the last HW Open House - wood, wood and more wood - this is a pine forest bitch slap to the senses in a handy 12 oz. bottle - a thick-chewy-maple sap-and-caramel-malt-oozing-down-the-gullet kind of libation - if you like piney, hoppy barleywines, this one is for you!

Thanks to Kinz for sharing this at the 3rd Richmond Gathering. Batch 64. Clear caramel color with a small light brown head. Sweet oak and pine aroma. Strong oak flavor, hints of vanilla, some caramel and pine in the background.
Oof.  Smells even woodier then the Fred.  Very oaky, piny scent.  I just cant take that much bitter tree flavour.
Pours a orange color with a tiny white head.  First thing you get hit with is the strong bourbon smell.  The taste is super and finishes like a shot of fine bourbon.  Alcohol is hidden.  Super brew!!

Batch 64 from Liquid Solutions.  Orange colored pour.  Smells like a bottle of Jim Beam.  Slighty hoppy and malty smelling too.  Alan makes great beers, and this is an example of that.  This is like drinking a very smooth bottle of Jim.  Nice little hop kick to back it up at the end.  Very good, worthy of its position on this site.  I can only imagine it when it was the 6 year old samples.  Glad I have more of this to hang on to, for a long time.  Thanks for brewing this one for us Alan.

Oh hell yeah! This beer really filled out everything normal ol Fred was missing. Or maybe I am just an oak nut. The aroma is buttery oak on top of the fresh english hops of Fred and warm caramel. Once this baby enters the mouth, the oak just explodes into creamy goodness, with great sage, roast, bitter herbs, chocolate, parsley. There is still alcohol in the mouth but it is so creamy and rich that Im still giving it a 5 for palate. This is one hell of a beer! I wish I got more than just 3.

!2 oz bottle poured a murky caramel orange color with the aroma of sweet over ripe fruits, oak and vanilla.
Flavor is sweet malts, ripe fruits, caramel, wood, with sweet alcohol warming finish.
Very good beer. Thanks Bockyhorsey!

Bottle 12oz. Batch 64. Aroma had an alcohol presence along with vanilla, wet wood. Hazy yellow with a fire orange middle for body with a halo ring head resting on top of body. Alcohol dominance at first like a shot of whiskey. Beer mellowed out with a smooth wood and toffee flavor. Definitely a sipping beer. Fortunately for me this order from Liquid solutions came though unlike the last.

batch #64 12oz bottle, ratebeer special, of course.  hazy orangey-amber color, thin creamy light tan head that goes quickly.  aroma is sweet syrupy malt like cherries in brandy.  vanilla extract, tobacco, a little hop, and wildflower aromas too.  flavor is strong sweet malt like sweet vermouth, dried calmyra figs, and some soothing brandy-like alcohol.  faint cherry and vanilla extract too.  a bit of dryness in the finish.  kind of woody in the finish also.  faint bit of ash in the aftertaste but very mild.  my favorite HOTD, great work.  bummed out the caps werent fully pressed, since I dont have a capper but Id like to cellar a few.

An impressive barley wine.  The hazy amber body surprised me.  Im used to a dark pour.  The aroma was strong with malts, hops evident, some smoke, hints of oak, toffee/molasses, alcohol, vanilla, and buttered rum.  Full bodied and smooth.  The flavor was deep and rich, with all the elements in the aroma making encores.  Warm on the way down and possessing depth of character and good balance of the elements.  Excellent.

Dark and slightly orangy. Thin white web of lacing. Aroma is seems pretty simple. Aroma is spicy, cinnimon but very dry. Im guessing this can be attributed to the oak. The flavor is very spicy lots of spicy and maybe some dry hops. Oaky dryness. Very oaky. Good. But not awesome.

Sampled and compared with standard Fred (Batch 56).  Golden color.  Some passion fruit (tangerine and orange) and other hop derived fruit notes in the nose, with hints of raw whiskey.  The nose isnt very expressive overall (especially compared to standard Fred) and it really is lacking oak aromatics.  I smell plenty of whiskey, but want more vanilla, toasted oak and coconut.  Upon tasting, I want more oak.  Typical supporting oak flavors are missing and it seems like the barrel did nothing but add whiskey flavors, not much else.  Where is my coconut and vanilla that I love in bourbon barrel aged beers?  Is my palate shot?  Some fruit notes blend with the whiskey, perhaps some lemon and apricot.  Overall, drinking this left much to be desired.  Oh well.  Side by side, I liked standard Fred much better.

Bottle from Liquidsolutions.com.  Dark amber with a thin and short lasting tan head.  Smells like oak, vanilla, caramel, apple, red wine, wood and tobacco.  Tobacco, currant, caramel, apple, oak, vanilla and chocolate and hinted in the taste.  A touch of red wine too.  Full palate with citrus coming in.  A good deal of alcohol presense on the palate.  Certainly the best Ive had from Hair of the Dog.

Batch 64: Fiery copper pour with a small, white head that quickly recedes.  Oak dominates the nose, which is also laced with lemon zest, whiskey and sweet toffee.  Big oak taste expands on the tongue created a lush mouthfeel.  The oakiness helps bring forth flavors of burnt caramel, charred cookie, sweet chocolates, vanilla beans, and rum soaked plums.  The flavors blend beautifully and spiral into a long finish that is soft, smooth and real drinkable.  Leaves a light honey like feel on the tongue. Good god this is one for the books.  And one for the cellar - this will only get better with a little age.

Bottle from liquidsolutions.com.  Pours thick and amber with a nice creamy-white head.  Aroma is a blend of vanilla, cedar, and citrus.  An oaky scent seems to be lingering in the background.  Flavor is an onslaught of cigar tobacco, raisin, yeast, and a tinge of orange that sweetens the deal.  Im also detecting a bit of red wine in the background. A very woodsy aftertaste is also apparent.  Palate fully coats and leaves a lingering hint of the flavors.  A great beer; definitely worth another try, preferably on tap.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle, Batch 64. Pretty similar in appearance to the normal Fred: solid muddy-caramel colored with the same yellowish light tan head...but this is about where the biggest similarities stop. The aroma is big and woody, there is a ton of oak in the nose. Elements of vanilla, citrus, yeast and cherry seem to come through at points but they seem to be taking a backseat to the oak at this time...though the fruit/citrus  seems to come through more as it warms a bit. The flavor also holds a good amount of oak/wood character, a bit less vanilla and more bitter citrus hops, cherry, and a brief light sweet malt before it goes back to the bittering hop/wood combo. Warming ,smooth and bittersweet in the front leading to a punch of dry bitterness...back to a nice sweet malty feel and finishing long, bitter, toasty and dry. HOD certainly has a knack for making big complex brews that dont taste like anything else Ive had, while this is no exception, the oak aged profile does remind me of a lot of beers that arent even the same style...the oak seems a bit overpowering right now. Perhaps some age will cut down the oak dominance a bit a bring out all the other great flavors that are on the side stage at the momment.

Batch 64. Cloudy bronze, smallish tan head. It smells like fresh fruit, toast, vanilla, flowers (The Bride says Lillies) and oak. Very floral at first, then the the oak pops up, though fairly understated. Nice salty, citrusy hops, and a persistant black pepper and ppine flavor. As it warms, more of a malt character emerges - molasses, maple, even a bit a vinuous flavor. Something like chestnust or Brazil nuts in the finish.  Actually changes with each sip, and simply giving a laundry list of flavors doesnt really do it justice. Superbly blended and very complex, I cant wait to see how it ages.

Wow, this is like a liquid cinnamon scone dipped in butter and dragged around in mapley-vanilla icing. Utterly compelling, and it was a total surprise. In fact, the guy that handed it to me didnt tell me what it was, and my first thoughts were "Cinnamon!" and said so aloud. Then he made me guess - I thought, hmm, Immort Ale, no, thats not as sharp as this. Unbelievable tightly held flavors, huge beer, hold everything well, the aroma is fabulous. Spectacular tingly palate.

text: Bottle.  Batch 64.  Pours a very thick and hazy amber color, with hints of orange and brown.  No real head to speak off.  Aroma consists mainly of malt and oakiness.  Both are also very prevalent in the taste.  Perhaps a bit too much oak right now, but not to the point where it detracts from the experience.  This is a thick and hearty beverage.  Very nice mouthfeel.  A little bitterness on the back.

This was one of the bottles where the cap was a bit crooked, but the bottle pfsshed nicely and the beer had plenty of carbonation. A medium amber-brown. The aroma hit me just on the pour despite being a little stuffed up. I go to blow my nose and come back with clear sinuses and can finally pick out just was was assaulting my olfactory center despite the congestion and distance only minutes earlier. The combination of fresh wood and hops create the impression of cedar so that it smells like the inside of my wifes cedar chest. The wood comes out even stronger in the flavor bring with it notes vanilla and a slight astringency like chewing on a piece of wood. The beer itself is big enough to handle this making for a complex, hoppy barley wine. This could probably use a bit of age, so Im glad I got 6 bottles. This way I can trade a couple and still have a few left to cellar.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2007 Batch 64, Sampled June 2006
Pours a hazy, orangish amber color and is only lightly carbonated, but still summons forth a 1/2 finger thick, frothy tan colored head, which quickly disappears.  Spicy notes of phenolic oak, perhaps some tobacco and alcohol hit my nostrils as I take my first draught of the aroma.  Rich notes of buttery oak and vanillin soon follow, but the aroma never loses that spicy wood driven edge found in the initial whiff.  The aroma is clearly dominated by the oak notes.  Despite the totally unbalanced leanings of the aroma, I actually am enjoying the woody complexity of this beer.

Ah, the malt is in the flavor.  Up front this beer has rich malty notes of toffee, caramel and toasted grain.  The malt notes are soon joined by buttery oak notes that move to a finish that is a mix of spicy wood, bitter hops and a touch of alcohol.  The oak really lingers on in the finish as well, a combination of oak-butter and astringently tannic wood notes.  This beer is quite pungent, in both it barrel character and also its hop notes.  The hops, while at first not that evident, are here as a major contributor as well.  Zesty notes of sweet orange peel move into notes of tangerine and are jointed by menthol like notes pine.  The beer has an upfront bitterness that is noticeable from the start of your sip, through to the lingering finish.

The oak probably gets in the way of the drinkability of this beer, but it adds a whole other layer of complexity to this brew, that almost offsets the loss in drinkability.  I really like that the hop notes are still quite pungent in this brew, while it does not compare to a fresh Fred, it again adds lots of much needed complexity to offset the, perhaps, dominant oak character.  As the beer warms the flavor gains even more balance; that fresh Fred hop character steps up a bit and helps to balance out the oak notes even more.  While this beer has always been quite good during this journey through my 12oz bottle, this beer is only getting better as it warms up and as it slowly disappears from my glass.

Purchased via mail order: <a href=http://www.liquidsolutions.ws/main/>Liq Solutions

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2006 Bottle.  A great beer.  The label says it all- tobacco, oak, and sweet malt flavor.  Finish is spicey hot w/ alcohol.  Reminds me of a higher alcohol version of Fish Tail Old Woody.

Sample 4 months after release date:  Tobacco and oak notes are more subdued w/ alcohol more prevalent.  More like the regular version this time around.

Bottle: Hazy medium brown in color, very little head. Aroma, oak, some fruits, a nice sweetness to it, a bit of vanilla. Flavor is very decadent, thick rich malts, caramel, some fruity sweetness, bourbon and oak. Theres just enough hops to keep it from being overly sweet. Finish is very smooth, with almost no trace of the 10% alcohol. This brew is amazing. And as my first Hair of the Dog, I cant wait to try more. Well done.

Pours a dense, hazy, murky dishwater brown with a thin head. Sweet, fruity, spicy aroma with some peach, oak and multi-vitamin. Very oaky flavor. Quite tart, almost sour. Very bitter. Strange flavors, herbal and medicinal with oregano and a hint of rubber. I get some bile also. Im not sold. Perhaps aging it will clean it up.

12 Oz bottle, batch 64.
pours nicely with a small head of off-white, that coats the glass as it reluctantly subsides (still a thick scum after 20 minutres).
Aromatic even when cold, dried fruit and caramel come through at first. It gets bigger and headier as it warms.
Full bodied, very full and smooth.
Damn pity that only two poor b*stds at BA have gotten to try this. This one will age nicely, dont rush it. Vanilla and oak is just beginning to show. The regular Fred is an amazing brew and this is just another part of the "Fred Legacy". Great beer by HotD.

Bottle, thatnks to footbalm. Pours cloudy orange/browm, with a small, white head. Aromas are fruit, bourbon, wood, along with some caramel and hops. Flavors are fruit, caramel, bourbon, oak, hops, and alcohol. Really good stuff.

Bottle, from LiquidSolutions. Batch #64 Yeah Baby) Good nose, sweet. Fruity. ripe red fruits, oak/wood, whisky, little cereal. Tad hazy brownish orange, small head with good lacing. Sweet flavor, like aroma with an oaky bite. Not an overwhelming oak, but you know its there. Medium body, velvety creamy smooth mouthfeel bitter finish with a ABV drying effect. Very nice and I guess aging will improve by mellowing a little.

text: Yum! My bottle was also a bit murky, but could be from the fact that it sat in the fridge long enough to get cold. Its a reddish brown colour with a good sized white head that dwindles down to sticky lace. Very sweet malty aroma with some roast, caramel, and piney hops. Great thick and sticky mouth feel that is mostly sweet with subtle oakey flavours. Theres a bit of bitterness in there, but nothing offensive, and it doesnt cloud the other flavours. Im nto sur emy palate is developed enough to pick arpart this complex and inviting beer. I carefully sipped it and enjoyed every taste.

Pours a highly murky orangish brown mud color w/ a thick white head and thick sticky lacing all down the glass.  Fairly mild aroma to start picking up some w/ temperature but staying fairly subdued.  Buttery woody scents dominate over a light maple syrup and grass scent.  Very well blended.  Palate is rich mellow and creamy with some light carbonation.  Flavor is sweet and syruppy rich with nice dry oaky wood notes and touches of grass.  Reminiscents flavors of bourbon and butter.  Extremly good rich and complex beer.

Beer is a hazy, medium amber-brown color with a small, frothy, beige, almost totally diminishing head. The aroma is totally inviting and in-order: Malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, dark caramel; Hoppy with an evergreen-like, moderate herbal/dill note; Yeasty with a light note of bread, trace basement; Moderate-to-heavy notes of spicy alcohol, oak, trace of honey. The flavor is moderate-to-heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter, with a long, very warm, lightly bittersweet and lightly acidic finish. Lots of oaky retros, unusual coconutty aftertaste. The body is full, the texture is syrupy and the carbonation is soft.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2010 Batch 64. Inviting pour  cloudy copper with a creamy, tight-bubbled, off-white head that recedes to the rim. The aroma is full of oak  almost like being in a shed full of freshly split, green oak wood. There are notes of earthiness, leather, orange peel and alcohol. The flavor is dominated by the woodiness. Still, the beer starts sweet  brown sugar and ripe fruit  and quickly turns tart, then bitter. However, the warmer it gets, the more the sweet malts present themselves. The finish is peppery and warm. Throughout is the taste of wood. Medium body with a fairly clean, crisp palate with only a slight stickiness. Moderate to long finish. Looking forward to revisiting this batch in a couple of years.

Batch 64 revisited 1-8-2010. The heavy oak aroma and flavor has faded. Aroma is still sweet with brown sugar and fruits along with notes of earthiness and leather. The flavor is heavily sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes moderatley to heavily sweet and moderately bitter. Alcohol warming in the finish behind some lingering woodiness. Nice tartness behind the bitter. Medium body, velvety texture and light to moderate carbonation. Complex and interesting at every turn.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2009 Batch 64, bought from Liquid Solutions. Pours murky amber orange with an off white head. Great aroma of sweet pineapple, oak, and citrus hops. I enjoyed taking several wiffs prior to drinking. The sweet initial flavor is nice blend of tropical fruit, caramel, and west coast hops. The finish is warming, oaky, with a pleasant spicy bitterness that lingers. Overall, I pick up more fruit flavors that oak, especially as it warms. Interesting.This is real good, and I am curious to see how this ages. CELLAR CHECK 7-4-09. Hops are severely faded, and what is left is a sweet oaky vanilla bomb with warming alcohol presence. This is almost like a shot of Southern Comfort. No oxidation, but too sweet and unbalanced for my tastes with age on it. Fresh, it was stellar.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2006 Batch 64 bottle.  Pour offers an intriguing color...hazy gold/brown...what an intense aroma Im getting as I watch for any head at all to form.  I loved the plain old "Fred" so Im pretty amped about this stuff.  Aroma is all over the map...sweet, bourbon?, fruity, and oh that oakiness.  BIg alcohol warming flavor, big oak kick, big maltiness that drys out fast.  Whew.  Not sure how Ill be able to let some of this sit for a year or so, but this stuff really could benefit from the rest.  Its great now, but oh the possibilities...

Bottle. Batch 64. Thanks to Alan Sprints of Hair Of The Dog for making/bottling this for Ratebeer! Murky bronze with only fleeting bubbles on the surface. Nose is laden with luscious fresh cut oak aromas, light vanilla, sweet malts, soft alcohol, mild hops, fermenting fruits, and light caramel. Taste delves more into the oakiness, sweety malts, caramel, touch of brown sugar, alcohol notes, ripe fruit flavors, light hops, some buttery malts, and some odd spiciness. Body is a bit thick and chewy with some syrupyness. Light alcohol warrmth from this as well. Mild to almost no carbonation feel in the mouth. Gets dry towards the end as well. Some dryness around the edges too. Finishes much the way it begins - sweet malts, buttery notes, alcohol, ripened fruits, caramel, big oak notes and light brown sugar. Wonderful! This will age nicely!

12 oz bottle, batch #64.  Despite all the fuss and concern, I finally got one of these in my belly.  Pours a hazy caramel color with a light white head.  The aroma has tons of fruit, and caramel.  There is also noticeable burnt cotton candy, raisins, bourbon, dates and a creamy buttery hint.  Also (when colder) you get hints of spiciness that could be pine like hops and a metallic twang (disappears as it warms).  As for the flavorIts Hot!  Alcohol in abundance and LOTS of oak.  The sweetness is upfront and pleasant but it is bullied by the oak, congnac and creamy mouth feel.  You move quickly through a variety of tastes including dark fruit (pervasive but subtle) and caramel.  As it warms the flavors really come out and you get some licorice or sassafras and pine hints.  There are some wine like hints in there too.  As I noted you also get a buttery mouth feel once you get past the bitter/dry hop/oak.  Cant wait to see how this ages.

#1500 thanks to Lumpy. 12 oz bottle-poured cloudy orange yellow. Half a finger creamy beige head after the beer warmed a bit. Mild pear and citrus aroma with a bit of brown sugar. Flavor is fruits-pear, citrus and some spice like cinnamon and ginger. A little banana. Very full mouth feel. I like the oak taste and seem to prefer the new barrels, which I helped purchase, versus a barrel that had bourbon in it. Alcohol is well hidden. A very nice beer made by a great brewer for a great website. Thanks Alan.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2006 Ratebeer edition.  Odd pour as it looked lighter going into the glass than it actually was.  Medium, slightly cloudy amber color with very small head, good lacing.  Strong Chardonnay character in aroma and initially in taste.  Distracting but will it mellow with age?  Somewhat sweet and sticky but the finish is dry with enough hops to offset.  Appreciate the effort but it just did not do it for me.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2008 Initial rating 6/16/06: Pours an orangey brown with modest carbonation and a thin film of bubbles that sit pretty around the brim of the snifter.  What is amazing about the initial appearance of this beer is that it actually has a neck similar to wine.  Smells orange with toffee, raisins, bananas, cherries, whisky, some oak, butterscotch and cognac.  Tastes very oaky and toasty with figs, and some fruity esters.  Mouthfeel is rich and full with a nice warming finish.  The oak is still a bit overwhelming on this one.  It needs a good 1-2 years in the cellar before it will really come into its own.Ar: 9 App: 5 Fl:7 Pa: 4 Ov: 15Bottle sampled 12/29/07: Pour yields less carbonation than when it was fresh.  Aroma is dominated by lots of fruit and sweet malt.  The oakiness has faded back to a minor compliment rather than an overwhelming element.  This beer had mellowed out nicely and continued to improve. Ar: 10 App: 5 Fl:9 Pa: 4 Ov: 19

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2007 Batch #64 sampled on 7/03/07: Pours a slightly hazy dark copper mahogany with a frothy clingy lacing cream-colored head.  Aroma doesnt seem too different from the fresher sample but has mellowed some.  Still has a ton of fresh toasty oak character though with a touch of butterscotch in the nose.  Body is full and intensely complex with great sweet caramel and oak flavor along with subtle bittering hops, light fruity esters, and toffee.  Perfect balance of oak and sweet caramel malt which hides the alcohol masterfully.  I need more of this...

Batch #64 sampled on 6/16/06: Pours a hazy dark copper orange with a thin-lacing, frothy tan head.  Aroma of big toasted oak and caramel malt with light butterscotch and leather.  Body starts with a sweet viscous caramel maltiness revealing some fruity (mild grapes and cherries)complexities and a hint of brown sugar amid plenty of earthy toasted oak toward a slightly warming finish.  Very fresh now and the oak is almost overpowering, but a year or two of age and this will be really nice.

RB edition:  Pour is deep murky amber with floaties and a thin sticky off white head...looks just like the regular Fred...smell is vanilla, alcohol, grapes, caramel...mouthfeel is thick and syrupy...taste is definately overpowered by sweet oak...just strongly smokey wood flavor...good, but horribly distracting and imbalanced...some prune and tobacco flavors come out in the finish, once you get past the charred wood flavor...tasty still, but unlike regular Fred, I couldnt sit and just enjoy two or three...I can only handle one of these...I am still glad that I bought a ton of them...thanks Alan!!!  I know this will develop into something even more tremendous, but for the time being, it gets a 3 on palate because it is so out of whack...

Batch number 64, this was brewed specially on request of Joe Tucker at RateBeer.com, aged for six months in new American oak barrels, with aging info and serving instructions on the right side of label, poured carefully to leave sediment in the bottle, sampled at cellar temperature in a snifter.

Made a good appearance, poured a solid orange hued amber with a thin fizzy head that settled into a fine lacing, very minimal amount of sticking, medium carbonation.

Had a nose of caramel malts, piney and herbal hops, a light citrus, a subtle oak woodiness and whiffs of softly spiced alcohol.

A crisp, hop textured and smooth medium bodied mouth feel, good sipping drinkability.

Caramel malty with herbal licorice hoppiness, piney and citric as well, a smooth rolling bitterness in the palate, a citric fruitiness softly emerges in the middle along with a sweet maltiness and dry yeastiness, oak woody and a dryish herbal and malty finish with a tobacco leafiness lingering in the palate. The alcohol warmth is a bit spicy and kept underneath all other tastes, well masked, you never feel it strength until it is too late, dangerously quaffable.

Another great barley wine from Hair of the Dog, should only improve with age.  Thanks Alan and Joe!!

(RATEBEER BATCH #64.I MUST NOTE ALL FOUR OF MY BOTTLES WERE IMPROPERLY CAPPED)super murky orange/brown body with a nice white head that left a thick webbing as it sat.the aroma was a little lighter than expected,but what i could pick up was lots of oak and vanilla.if i tried real hard i could find some sweet malts in the nose as well.as i took the first sip i got a oak/vanilla rush.it was then followed by sweet candy and a bit of a sour note.the mouthfeel was on the medium side and the alcohol was well hidden.

Nice.  Batch 64, the RateBeer batch.  Poured a murky brown, probably because I didnt let it sit long enough for the sediment to fall out of suspension after its cross country road trip.  Low carbonation made for a smooth mouthfeel.  Aroma was a big shot of caramel malt, pine resin hop, and charred campfire wood.  Flavors matched, with a great assortment of dark fruits (plums, raisins, etc.) chiming in.  Vanilla also present.  This thing should age beautifully, but is awfully nice right now as well.

batch 64, poured a cloudy, murky orange when held to the light.  sitting in the glass it looks more bronze or copper, but with a bright light behind it, orange is my hue descriptor of choice. frothy white head that drops down to a thin layer of lacing that covers the entire surface area inside the glass, as well as clinging to the sides of my Duvel glass. Oak, raisin, grape, vanilla and caramel blend together in an aroma that is enticing and strong, but not over powering in any one dimension. Flavors of oak, toasted malt, resinous hops, caramel, and raisin make up the palate, with the oak being a bit on the strong side, but not enough that everything else is buried by it, but you do have to   look for it a bit. The mouthfeel is amazing..thick and syrupy, it clings to your lips while the slightly warming body coats the inside of your mouth and runs down your throat, leaving its warmth all the way down.  I will say i am anxious to let this sit for a while and mellow out a little in terms of the flavors evening out.  right now, its a superb beer, but i cant wait until it gets even better.  thanks to Alan and everyone else that put this together for us.

12-oz. bottle, Batch 64.  Pours a cloudy amber, bronze with a small and quickly diminishing off-white head, some spotty lacing.  Aroma is initially bourbon oak barrels with some medium roasted malt and faint yeast; nose is an herbal peppery aroma with maple notes.  Nutty, moderately bitter and acidic bourbon and oak flavor, some underlying sweetness, hints of hops with some palate drying characteristics, caramel toasted malt and doughy yeast, finish is slightly burning alcohol.  Full bodied and warm, creamy and smoth palate that does attempt to go dry.

Batch 64.  I poured this baby into my large brandy snifter so that it would amplify the aroma as it should.  The aroma is immediately met by my nose.  Its delighted.  Its sorta like apricots and muskmelon meets vanilla laden oak barrels that were lightly sprinkled with black pepper.  Yes, its barley wine smelling, but its very interestingly unique.  I can only imagine what the original HOTDFFTW smelled like.  6 years of barrel aging?  Wow!  This one, with only 6 months of aging, worked its magic.  The beers appearance is a very murky chestnut brown colored body with a thin but coating light khaki head.  Some thick lacing goes around the glass.  I take my first sip and the flavor is superb.  Very well blended.  My tongue is met with vanilla, oaky tannins, golden brown sugar, golden raisins, port wine, light sprinkling of fresh cracked black pepper.  Very nice.  The palate is nicely warming.  Reminds me that Im drinking.  :)  The body is rich, thick, lightly drying, and spicy.  This beer is superb.  I shoulda bought a whole case.

This is a very unique Barley Wine IMHO.
The oak is so mellow that in no way does it overpower what seems to be a fruit laden nectar. Just  a little hoppy with loads of what appears to me mangos  or some kind of exotic melon.
Alcohol is well masked and not very noticable. Sweet like most BWs but not overly syrupy. Hope to hell these do not start exploding.

Batch 64:  Very hazy deep orange-amber color with a small off-white head.  Probably would have been a clearer if I didnt drink it a few hours from it arriving from Oregon.  The aroma is very woody...big hunks of wood.  Strong vanilla with notes of brown sugar, fruit and some alcohol and light smoke.  Fruity flavor with a mild tartness, sugar, big wood, vanilla and some alcohol.  The wood really shows up in the finish too.  The finish drys out a little with a mild bitterness of fruit stones.  Nice warmth.  Medium to full bodied and silky but not so thick that you cant drink a full bottle.  I cant wait to see how the oak, malt, and alcohol age.  Hopefully I can save at least one for 5 years not that it needs it.  Drinks just fine now.

Re-rate (no # change) 10 minutes later.  The last few ounces were left to get warm and the fruit really explodes in the aroma and flavor.  The mouthfeel gets real soft.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2007 12oz. bottle (RB Batch 64). Hazy orange/amber color with a medium sized off white head. Awesome aroma! Aroma was initially tart and citrusy, followed by lots of oak, toffee, vanilla, mild smoke and alcohol. Kept sniffing for a good five minutes before the first sip. Big time oak flavor with lots of alcohol present. Toffee, vanilla and a tartness that reminds me of grapefruit pith. Nice warming alcohol finish. I could have sworn the alcohol was higher than 10%. In some beers you like the way the alcohol is hidden. In this beer the alcohol presence adds to the overall complexity of the beer. Thank you Alan Sprints!

Great stuff.  Special ratebeer.com bottle from liquid solutions.  So yummy.  All the molassas, caramel, raisin, dark dried fruit in the aroma.  Aromas were much sweeter than the flavor came off.  Flavor brought out the wood.  Oak and Smoke.  Then the other flavors came in too.  Some alcohol, but not much really.  Oh So Good

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2006 Bottle from the RB release. A deeper amber color than the stock Fred, reddish hues when backlit. Redolent with oak in the nose, with a definite hop presence, malt is honey-like, sweet and subtle. Moderate tannish/khaki head and spotty lacing. Full bodied and quite smooth. For using a fresh, American oak barrels the wood presence doesnt overwhelm as much as I anticipated. Vanilla, some honey and moderate tannins blend quite nicely with the base beer. Pleasant hop bitterness and flavor towards the finish. This is one to age and savor on special moments!!

Bottle sampled 26 November 06. Appearance notes remain the same. Still huge oak in the nose, loads of tannins. Tart and drying feel. Holding up quite nicely, this one was from a barely capped bottle. More than acceptable.

12oz bottle from batch 64 (ratebeer.com 2006 release).  Pours translucent deep amber.  No light rays pass directly through this stuff.  Subtle aroma (though I will admit to be getting over a cold) of earthy apples and citrus, with some alcohol and oak.  In the mouth it starts with honey, then the oak comes in with vanilla, followed by alcohol.  Aftertaste literally tingles on the tongue (I get the same sensation from grapefruit juice), and is heavy with oak.  Definite alcohol warming.  Subsequent swallows get more earthy and oaky, with a slight bitterness.  Very mellow and lush in the mouth.  If this is really a barley wine, its the best Ive tasted.  The hotd web site cites it as a "golden strong ale", though. This beer is an amazing piece of craftsmanship, and Im honored to have been able to sample it.  It is one of two beers (the other being a 2005 Dark Lord) where everything is almost perfectly in balance (personally, I might like the oak toned down a hair, but Im pretty anti-oak).  It doesnt have any stand-out attribute, which is whats so outstanding in a big beer.

Bottle poured a beautiful cloudy copper with a small but lingering light amber head. Aromas of toasty oak, carmel, vanilla, fruitiness and a hint of honey. Palate was medium bodied and very smoooth. Flavors of [heaven?] vanilla, toasty oak, a hint of good bourbon, apples, pears, melon and light citrus with an extremely pleasent lingering bittersweet finish!!! Thanks Alan, this beer really rocks!

Just got this wonderful beer from Liquid Solutions.  Hazy orange-amber, very slight head, wonderful aroma - woody, fruity and moss, very complex.  The first hit is alcohol, then a wonderful woodsy, grass and maybe hay rolls over the tongue with a hoppy after taste.  The beer has a very chewy moutn feel.  As this beer warms, I get more citrus.  This is an incredible beer.  Thanks, Alan.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2009 Rerate 06 Ratebeer special release.  Deep amber-orange beer with a huge tan-beige head.  Aroma is lovely.  Soft fruity nose.  Lightly peachy with a lot of strong vineous notes.  A nice sweet vanilla oakiness and a bit of mintiness on the back.  Its aded really nicely... sweet and vineous with a lot of woody complexity.  Earthy/chewy hoppiness.  Very delicious.
8 4 8 4 17
Pale amber beer, no head.  Big malty, slightly salty aroma.  Sweet heavy toffee, big oaky aroma, woody and hoppy resin.  Strong peppery alcoholic aroma and flavour.  Oaky character and sweet maltiness.  
8 3 8 3 15

The stand out beer at Lucky Baldwins barley wine fest 2005. How amazed I was to find it there.

Clouded amber hue, good head formation. Strong fruity, prune, aroma, fairly creay with milder tropical fruity balance. Strong sweet fruitiness on the palate, jammy, raisins and cherries, touch of vanilla, warming alcohol finish. Very port like. Exceptional.
UPDATED: MAR 11, 2005 Alan gave us a sample at the brewery and it was just wonderful.  Oaky, some nice oxidized character and that great malt of Fred.  Such a nice beer...

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2006 6/23/06.  Poured out of 12 oz. bottle, obtained from Liquid Solutions via mail order 6/9/06.  RateBeer Release.  RERATE.  Lightly hazy orange caramel color with a moderate-to-thin, mostly tightly-formed light cream head, fading slowly to a thin surface dusting.  Lacing is average-- spotty, uneven, but finely sanded and somewhat sticky where it falls.  Aroma is wicked as ever, but not quite what I remember-- extremely fruity, yeasty, hypnotically woody with a waxy, sweet-and-sour vanilla essence.  The caramel character is even doughy like cinnamon cookies.  Flavor is a little rough in comparison, plenty of tobacco (a mixture of sweet, soft new cigar and spent ash-- theres a definite ashen prickle to this) and still featuring the wax-wood and vanilla, but also met with a bubblegummy and prickly hop presence, just a bit too raw at this stage (although with the sourness hinted at in the nose, Im really not quite sure how this will age).  Mouthfeel is outstanding-- fine carbonation is fluffy, fuzzy and tingling, intertwined with the snippy alcohol bite and gentle warmth, all surrounding a full body that packs an astoundingly dry, sappy finish.  Vanilla, dry wood, faint vinous sourness and fruitiness, over-toasted sugar cookies where Mom forgot to add the sugar.  Still, quite a treat.  Thanks, Mom!
9/3/8/5/17/4.2

ORIGINAL RATING: 8/28/04.  Poured out of 1.5 L bottle, sampled at Dr. Bill and Steinys 8th Annual 12-Hour Beer Festival in Orange, CA 8/28/04.  Pours a lightly hazy orange-caramel color.  Slight head that lingers in a rocky ring.  Not much lacing at all.  Lovely round caramel nose and a very mellow, subdued wood character.  Very subtle and inviting.  Touch of sweetness and bitter hops.  Huge body.  Touch of wood sourness masking an awesome velvety sweetness and then finally a dirty bitter malt.  Perhaps too much wood, but only slightly.  Amazing body.  Slight carbonation tingle, big alcohol and very dry, numbing finish.  It actually seems HIGHER than 10% ABV, but in a very good way.  A bit of pith in the flavor, a bit of caramel and brown sugar.  Thick, viscous and chewy. 9/3/8/4/18/4.2

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2006 Bottle. Head is initially small, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy medium amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, caramel), lightly to moderately hoppy (apricot, orange, resin), with a strong note of raw wood, notes of alcohol, candy, toffee, vanilla. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, watery/syrupy texture, soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Not as good as when I had it at the brewery (which was aged longer IIRC).  Too much raw wood in the nose, but otherwise pretty nice.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2006 RBSG04, DRAFT: Amber-orange with a thin but creamy head. Awesome nose: woodsy, wholesome, fresh, and a little yeasty. Smooth and thick texture. Very complex with meaty malt flavors. Big wood notes. Melded hops, smooth and pleasant. Sweet and warming. A real pleasure to drink.    BOTTLE, RATEBEER SPECIAL RELEASE 2006: Some may have had capping issues, but my bottles were great ... opened with a healthy pfsst. Hazy and medium amber. Nose smelled of fermented apples in a wood barrel full of caramel. Creamy and weighty palate; nice carb level. Toffee and toast. Warming alcohol. Nippy hops.

RBSG 2004, on cask at the brewery:  7 year old sample, bright orange color without much head. Sharp wood aroma with vanilla and a lambic-like funk.  Starts and ends sweet, fizzy mouthfeel, long fruity aftertaste.

On tap at the brewery during the RBSG 04.  Buttery nose with tons of oak sawdust, especially in the exhale.  Many more fruity notes than Fred not from the Wood.  I dont know if it is the wood, but the flavors evoke an old red wine.  Delicious beer.

Tap at the brewery: 7 years old!!  Incredibly complex; highly rich and woody aroma, that almost knocked me out flat on the ground of this freakin awesome brewery!!  Cedar, some alcohol, pear, banana in the flavor.  Great!!

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 Sampled at the brewery in 2004, I was drinking the 8 year old vintage, which I guess puts it at about 1996 or 1997. Appears golden orange, absolutely beautiful nose of wood, scotch, cherries and yeast.  A little bite at the back of the throat, then a smooth and silky texture before a sharp finish of scotch and cherries.  The RB release is an entirely different rating (and more lengthy).  Hopefully Ill get that posted some time.

See above.  I never really got the 2006/RB batch review posted, but I still have 1/2 case sitting around.  Right now Im drinking the new 2008, its bright, sharp, snappy and biting on the tongue.  Spiced honey and sweet Irish whiskey... mmm good.

RBSG 04. Thanks again to Alan Sprints for his generosity.
Straight from the cask, this is a beauty. Gorgeous complex aroma along with a great drinking flavor make this a wonderful beer.

On tap at the brewery RBSG 04: Pours a deeper golden then the new fred. Very little head but decent lacing. Aromas of Oaky sourness and the hops that it has sat on. So many flavors in such a small glass. Starts sour with some residual sweetness and a slight herbal hoppiness. Very sour in the middle and ends with just the slightest hint of bitterness. The alcohol is never apparent. The sourness from the oak is a bit too much for me but I am sure glad I got to try this and Im sure for some, this would be a favorite.

Medium orange color. Aroma is fruity, wood and oak. A medium to full-bodied barley wine This is Fred to an extreme. Malts are fruity, sweet, orange and citrus. Hops are prevalent, but cask aging has muted the hop alpha acids quite a bit. Nice before, now awesomely smooth. Touches of orange, hops flavors and malts. Mouthfeel is very smooth. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2005 Tap @ HotD Tour for RBSG 04Fred in all senses except full of oak & salty fruit. The tail is balanced & full, very similar to the original yet vastly different at the same time.

ReRate @ Oakes 05 Xmas Party - Woody, light, maple syrup, salty, no head, no lacing. Excellent and woody. I plan to pick up a case of this when its available.

RBSG04. Sweet and malty aroma with lots of caramel taste. Amber color with a white head that leaves good lacing. Taste has a great oak accent complimenting the malty toffee body and ending with a good bitterness to balance. Right from the oak barrel, thanks Alan.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2006 Uh, see my other comments on the original. Ive had both, it was a long time ago that I had this one though. Strange that this is finally being listed as a different beer. 
Rerate, 7-06: Special RB release thing. Pours a murky, glowing brown/orange with a very thin head. Pretty much no carbonation. Fruity aroma of cherries, moderate sweetness, defined oak presence. Taste is lots of oak up front. Soft, fruity sweetness. Noticable floral flavors. Alcohol present but quite well hidden. Palate is incredibly smooth, velvity, so nice. This beer is still great, although a little rough, maybe a little hot right now. I have a feeling it will age quite nicely. Rating reflects previous tasting notes, but this is easily a 4 or better at this stage.

Simply brilliant. The best by far of the "from the wood" series. Clear amber with a huge tight dense manilla head. The aroma is to die for. huge oak, vanilla, vinous, smoky amalgamation. The flavor holds its own, pronounced vanilla/oak woodiness along with sweet toffee and vinous qualities. Full body that just evvelopes your palate in a pillow of goodness. Thank you Alan for sharing this and making our visit so wonderful!

(RBSG04) Lightly hazed amber body topped by beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, toffee, vinous, light smoke, oak.  Taste is medium sweet, toffee, vinous, oak, some smoke, finishing with some alcohol burn.  Medium full body, and oh so smooth!  The highlight of the weekend for me.

Amber with a tannish head and webbed lacing. Very woody, mostly oak, aromas. Very vinous. Sweet malts: caramel or toffee. Hints of vanilla as well. The vinous qualities carry over to the flavors. Spicy as well as oaky. Caramel and other sweet malts. Nice and hoppy. Thick and syrupy finishing sweet and sour.
